subsubtopic: REQUEST FOR ENSHRINEMENT OF HOSPITAL AND MEDICAL CARE
speechtext:
That, in the opinion of this House, the Constitution should
enshrine the obligation for the government to provide universal,
publicly funded hospital and medical care to all citizens.
She said: Mr. Speaker, in a matter of days, the first ministers of this country will meet in the hope of drafting a constitutional accord that will be acceptable not only to themselves but to Canadians.
These ministers will collectively be the target of public wrath if they fail to reach an agreement that justifies so many years of constitutional wrangling at taxpayers' expense.
The Prime Minister will have to reconcile the crippling price that the nation paid for his pursuit of a footnote in history. The Canadian Confederation was put at risk to extinguish the regional discontent that his government resurrected and inflamed. This government opened a Pandora's box and the entire nation has been engulfed in the fall-out. Millions of dollars of taxpayers' money have already been lost while the nation's economic crisis has been sorely neglected and mismanaged by this government.
After investing so much in a flawed and misdirected process, Canadians are now demanding a return. They will not settle for a raw deal that merely shifts powers among the politicians. Most citizens see no benefit in the transfer of authority from one bureaucracy to another. In
the end they will be asking whether all they got from the last several years of constitutional noise was the bill. Voters in any national referendum will be expecting an accord that is intimately relevant to their lives and their needs.
That is the reason I am proposing here today:
That, in the opinion of this House, the Constitution should enshrine
the obligation for the government to provide universal, publicly
funded hospital and medical care to all citizens.
There is nothing more relevant to Canadians than their health. From St. John's to Victoria, Canadians regard our system of universal health care as the most identifiable privilege of being on Canadian soil.
The right of Canadians to health care is not protected by our Constitution and consequently it must endure the deliberate efforts of the current government to pillage our health care resources to finance their experiment in neo-Conservative dogma, the abandonment of the just society.
Since 1984 this government has made seven unilateral reductions in transfer payments to the provinces for health and post-secondary education. This will represent a $97.6 billion loss to these services by the year 2000. This government's commitment to health care is clearly focused on ways to dismantle it.
On March 21 the Minister of National Health and Welfare terrified many Canadians by labelling medicare as sacred. We all know that sacred in Tory double-speak means next in line for the axe. Within 10 years the federal government will no longer be making any significant cash contributions to health care in this country. It will no longer be able to enforce the provisions of the Canada Health Act by threatening to withhold payments. This will open the door to the imposition of user fees by provincial governments.
User fees will be a decisive first step toward an American-style system of commercial health care. It is a system where those with the means to pay are served, but those unable to pay must go without or lose their homes or life savings to pay for treatment. American health care is nothing more than a half trillion dollars a

June 8, 1992
Private Members' Business
year extortion racket. Americans must pay up or risk bodily harm by being denied treatment.
In pre-Tory Canada our focus was the quality of medical care as opposed to the size of medical profits, a matter which dominates attention south of the border. Canadians are too civilized to accept the barbarism of cash and carry medicine which this government is ready to import from the United States. This is one product that all Canadians want stopped at the border.
Already under-funding of Canadian health care has caused many patients to escape lengthening waiting lists for elective surgery or specialized tests by travelling to the United States where timely treatment is available although only at a premium. Effectively Canadian governments have contracted out certain services to American facilities by not making the same services sufficiently available in Canada. Such measures threaten the comprehensiveness of health care services in Canada and make them a more appealing target for privatization.
Canadians need their Constitution to insulate medicare from the chills of ever-changing political agendas. Even the loud advocate of the social charter, the NDP premier of Ontario, backed away from full protection of medicare when he chose to cut health services in his own province rather than curtail his socialist agenda.
The temptation to shirk the largest and most important responsibility of his government was too great for Premier Rae to resist. The social charter now declawed and renamed the social covenant is little more than social fantasy.
If a government were to renege on its so-called commitment to medicare utterly there would be no recourse at all through the courts on constitutional grounds. However, the social covenant may lull many Canadians into being complacent about the continuing threats to their health care system. Some will believe the social covenant will morally bind all governments to preserve and promote universal health care, but most Canadians know only too well that commitments do not bind political leadership. Only the courts can do that.
Canadians do understand the difference between a legal right and a rhetorical blight. A right not protected
by the courts is no right at all. A social covenant will not deter the current federal and provincial governments from discrediting our medicare system through a policy of decay that will ultimately render medicare unable to meet the needs of Canadians.
A social covenant will fail to raise the status of medicare on either the big business or the big labour agenda. Canadians are justifiably suspicious of political commitments and the politicians who glibly make them.
They understand the fate of Canadian medicare is in the hands of individuals who would never feel personally threatened by American style cash before cure health care. They know that members of this House and other legislatures across the country are in general people who have a hard time relating to the working poor in this country because they have only experienced poverty as spectators.
Many politicians cannot believe that a family would find U.S. medical insurance deductibles of $250 to be cause to postpone or forgo treatment even for their children. The struggle to make ends meet is foreign to the opponents of medicare. We in this place must understand that we are each creations of our own experiences. We must defiantly reject the message that is promoted by the right wing groups who tell us that we have shared too much and those who cannot afford are not deserving.
That is the philosophy that has created so much suffering and disharmony in the United States, but medicare is not merely a social program for the less fortunate. It is a security blanket for every member of our society, rich or poor.
Canadians do not have to negotiate with insurance brokers to be sure their children will get the care they need if they fall ill. No Canadian will have to cancel an operation because his employer laid him off and cancelled his health insurance. We as Canadians have a security, a peace of mind that cannot be found among American workers.
Unfortunately what Canadians have taken for granted their government has taken to the pawnbrokers. The enemies of medicare will not only deny the benefits that universal health care services offer to the majority of Canadians, but will also ignore the undeniable economic benefits to our nation as a whole. We have been able to
June 8, 1992

insure all Canadians using less than 9 per cent of our gross national product when it costs the United States 11 per cent to operate a private system that leaves 40 million people bereft of any medical protection at all.
Canadians understand what the demise of universal health care will mean to them and to their families. Many have already experienced the culture shock that comes with U.S. medical practices.
While sensational stories of people being denied life-saving treatment and the potential for medical refugees coming to Canada from the United States may impress television viewers, Canadians travelling to the United States experience firsthand the inhumanity of the U.S. system. Patients are treated as customers while health care workers are more bill collectors than they are caregivers.
One of my own constituents recounted an occasion while vacationing in Florida when his five-year old daughter fell in a bathtub and required stitches to close the cuts to her face. Her father was shocked and enraged when the hospital workers refused to treat his bleeding five-year old child unless he paid in advance or produced insurance documents.
Fortunately he had the necessary insurance but, nevertheless, the experience left him and his family eager to return to medical civilization north of the border.
This was not a dramatic case of life and death but demonstrated the humiliation and despair that is felt by Americans who do not have full medical coverage. Forty million people in the United States who are not covered by any insurance plan live in fear of the day that they will need medical treatment and be denied.
We in Canada like to believe that we live in a more caring and less predatory society than the United States.
It is experiences like the one I just described that have caused Canadian universal medicare to be so prized and the American alternative so despised. So cherished is medicare in Canada that there are many groups that would claim to have fathered the Canadian philosophy of universal medicare.
Private Members' Business
We on this side of the House know that medicare was conceived at the national Liberal convention in 1919 in a speech by William Lyon Mackenzie King. He envisioned more than seven decades ago that Canada should have a system of insurance against sickness. He called for effective legislation for the conservation of human health.
It was not acceptable for a worker when sick to be helpless in the matter of meeting the great problems of invalidity, said King. He and his successors as Leader of the Liberal Party of Canada fought against great adversity to implement the universal health care we enjoy today.
Opposition came from short-sighted organizations whose own economic position, they thought, was enhanced by the suffering and insecurity endured by those who could not afford the medical treatment available to those with the means to pay.
While Liberal governments braved the scorn of the intolerant, the greedy and the indifferent, the voices of those who would have us reverse our progress toward a more civilized society have not yet been silenced.
If universal publicly funded health care is not enshrined in the Constitution as a justiciable right, the implications will not be lost on the Canadian public.
The NDP Government of British Columbia has already brought in health care premiums that have caused a small but significant portion of its population to be uninsured and financially vulnerable to sickness. Effectively universal health care has already been compromised by the NDP government in British Columbia.
It is not surprising to find that this particular government will not sign an agreement that will make its own policies unconstitutional.
This is the dilemma that gave birth to the toothless social covenant. Canadians have learned to anticipate the worst from their governments. They know that a government unprepared to protect universal medicare is a government preparing to dismember it. That is the basis for our Liberal dissent position in the report of the Beaudoin-Dobbie committee where we advocated precisely the terms of the motion before the House today.

June 8, 1992
Private Members' Business
Unlike the other national parties we Liberals are not willing to compromise on our obligation and responsibility to uphold the principles of universality and fairness in health care.
Canadians should scrutinize the events of the next few days very closely indeed. Front page promises and back page retractions have formed the strategy of governments of the day for too long. The entrenchment of medicare will distinguish this round of constitutional bickering by yielding a tangible and recognizable benefit to Canadians from every part of this country.
If this constitutional round were able to arrest the decay of Canadian medicare then Canadians would truly be better off through the efforts of politicians, and that would be historic.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Solicitor General of Canada
subsubtopic: REQUEST FOR ENSHRINEMENT OF HOSPITAL AND MEDICAL CARE
speechtext:
Thank you, Mr. Speaker, for the opportunity to speak this morning on the federal government's commitment to vital social programs, notably health care.
I would like to assure the House that the government's commitment to universal health care services is not in question. The Canada Health Act ensures that all Canadians, wherever they reside, are entitled to equal access to hospital and medical care. The government has reaffirmed this commitment time and time again.
Our commitment to health care is only one example of the government's efforts to improve the well-being of Canadians. I would like to take a few moments to describe some of the other recent social initiatives of this government.
The health and well-being of our children are a primary concern of this government. In the throne speech, we said our objective is to see our children "better educated, better protected and better nurtured so that they can make their own contributions to our future".
As you know, Mr. Speaker, the government has recently announced major initiatives to assist children and their families. In the February budget, the government proposed a new child benefit which is fairer and simpler than the patchwork of previous income support measures for families with children.
The proposed child benefit will consolidate the existing family allowances, child tax credit and dependent child credit into a single monthly tax-free benefit. It is simpler, fairer, more responsive and more generous than the current measures in place.

I would like to comment on each of these points in turn.
It is simpler. It will replace today's patchwork of measures with one monthly payment. Unlike family allowances, these payments will be tax free. Parents will know what benefits they receive and can apply their full value to meeting their children's needs.
It is also fairer. It will go to families who need it. As family income increases, the benefit received will decrease. It is also fairer because families in similar income brackets will be treated in a similar way. Unlike the present system, it does not matter whether one or both parents work. The level of benefits is based on the income of the family.
It is more responsive. Tax free payments will be received by parents every month to help them meet their children's needs.
This system is also more generous. Until now, some $4.5 billion per year has been provided by the federal government for income transfers for children. Over the next five years, the proposed child benefit will put an additional $2.1 billion in the hands of Canadian families with children. Over-all, this initiative will result in a more targeted and effective system of benefits.
The government has also been keenly aware that a child's future health and well-being can be jeopardized by risks such as low birth weight, injuries, malnutrition and neglect.
We have responded with the recent announcement of Brighter Futures, and with the child development initiative aimed at preventing and reducing conditions of risk among children. The government intends to devote $500 million over the next five years to this program directed at intervention in the early stages of the lives of children at risk. By children at risk, I mean children who face greater than normal risks of poor health and nutrition, mental health problems, disability or injury, or abuse and neglect.
The child development initiative will help ensure that children get a good start. A good start increases the likelihood that a child will achieve his or her full potential later in life. At the same time, our early investment in a child's development can lower costs for social assistance, health care and law enforcement in the years to come.
Private Members' Business
The initiatives I have described testify to our strong commitment to improve the health and well-being of needy children. I should add that the federal government is not alone in this commitment. We rely on strong partnerships with all Canadians to secure a better future for our children. We recognize that healthy and well-adjusted children represent an essential investment in the future for all of us.
In the context of the motion before us this morning, we should perhaps remind ourselves of the partnership which currently exists between the federal government and provincial governments for the delivery of these vital programs and services.
For example, the delivery of health services is a constitutional responsibility of the provinces. It is their responsibility to determine needs, to make services available and to manage health costs. The primary role of the Government of Canada is to make a financial contribution in support of provincial health programs. Under Established Programs Financing, transfers to provinces for insured hospital and medical services and extended health care will be $14.8 billion in the current fiscal year.
In addition, the less wealthy provinces of Canada will receive equalization transfers totalling more than $8 billion this year. Equalization is provided to provinces on an unconditional basis. Each province is free to allocate these funds according to its own needs and priorities, including medical and hospital care.
The motion before us asks this House to enshrine in the Constitution the obligation of the federal government to provide universal, publicly funded hospital and medical care to all citizens.
We have seen that this government has not needed a constitutional directive in order to demonstrate its commitment to medicare. Our commitment to providing quality health care for all Canadians is not in question.
Nevertheless the motion before us raises an interesting issue, one of many on which this government has consulted Canadians in the current round of constitutional negotiations.
In March the Special Joint Committee on a Renewed Canada released a unanimous report. This report made a variety of recommendations to assist the government in renewing the Canadian federation. The committee dis-

June 8, 1992
Private Members' Business
cussed the issue that is before us today. It looked at the government's commitment to vital social programs, including health care. The committee recommended a social covenant as a means of expressing governmental commitments to social programs which Canadians see as part of their national identity.
This covenant would be achieved by adding a new section to section 36 of the Constitution Act, 1982. Among other things, the new section would reaffirm the commitment of all governments in Canada to fostering comprehensive, universal, portable, publicly administered and accessible health care. These are the commitments that are now contained in the Canada Health Act.
The joint parliamentary committee also recommended that the compliance of governments with the social covenant must be subject to public review, including public hearings and periodic reports by a specialized commission.
Therefore, the motion before us today is, in fact, part of the much broader package of issues under consideration as the government works to renew the Canadian federation. Representatives of the provinces have shown considerable interest in the idea of a social covenant. The federal government's position on this constitutional issue will always be consistent with our long-standing commitment to health care.
In closing, I would acknowledge that all members share the high priority this government attaches to the health and well-being of Canadians. The strength of that commitment is not in question.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is indeed a pleasure for me to join the debate on the motion presented by the member for Mississauga East.
I have known the member for Mississauga East for many years. We have been on several delegations together. I know she is a very bright, intelligent and well-meaning person. That is why I was so surprised at some of the comments she made in her speech. I am particularly surprised at her lack of historic knowledge.
The member tried to lay claim to medicare as a Liberal invention by stating that in 1919 at the Liberal convention William Lyon Mackenzie King enunciated the notion of a universal medical care system. While the Tories and the Liberals in the past have fought over who was responsible in terms of who is the father of medicare, it is true that the Diefenbaker government of the day appointed the Hall commission and it is true that the Liberal government of Mr. Pearson introduced the legislation, but let me tell you that the mother of medicare was the province of Saskatchewan and Woodrow S. Lloyd as its premier. They suffered the birth pains of medicare.
I was there when we had our "Keep Our Doctors" committee, when the doctors in Saskatchewan went out on strike, funded at the time by the American Medical Association. I was there when the then premier Ross Thatcher went to the legislature and kicked on the doors of the legislature. That was the Liberal history on medicare in Saskatchewan. The major source of opposition to medicare came from the Liberals in the province of Saskatchewan.
The hon. member is particularly attacking the NDP provinces. She incorrectly states that the province of British Columbia under Premier Harcourt introduced health premiums. The fact is that B.C. under the Socreds have had health premiums for years. She also attacked the Government of Ontario, Mr. Bob Rae's government, claiming that because of the Rae government going on its socialist agenda, it could not find enough money to properly fund medicare.
I know we are living in an age that George Orwell described as 1984. I have generally attributed that double-think to the Tories, but I am afraid it has also infected the Liberals. Had Premier Rae put more money into hospitalization, the hon. member would have said: "Ah, ha, that is another indication of the socialist agenda". I ask, what socialist agenda? The Ontario government inherited a deficit situation from the Liberals, accelerated by the economic policies of this Tory government. It is trying to do its best to maintain social and health programs and making certain that the amount of interest it pays on the deficit is reduced as much as possible.
It is not an easy task, but it is not their fault. It is something they inherited from the Liberals and from the federal Tbiy policy.
June 8, 1992

I heard the hon. member talk a little bit about the cutbacks to the EPF, the program that transfers federal funds and tax points to the provinces. The Tory action has accelerated the decrease in what the provinces are getting. Let us not forget that this was started by the Liberals when they were in government under Pierre Trudeau. Half of the cutbacks and the costs to the provinces for medicare is because of the cutbacks introduced by the Liberals and because of the ceiling on revenue sharing, the six and five. It used to be that federal contributions to health care in this country amounted to roughly 50 per cent. The reality today is that the federal contribution comes to about 30 per cent of the total costs of medicare.
Do not be impressed when you see the Liberals crying crocodile tears over medicare. That is a farce. They were responsible. Let us have a look at some of the figures. For example, in the province of Ontario the provincial government is supposed to be carrying on the socialist agenda.
Since the cutbacks in the EPF, there has been a total loss of revenue to the province of Ontario of some $12,295 billion. Almost $6.3 billion can be attributed to the elimination of revenue guarantees and the six and five. In other words, half the money Ontario has lost because of the cutbacks in EPF is the result of Liberal cutbacks.
Let us look at B.C. where it is exactly the same. There is a total loss of some $6.8 billion of which almost $3 billion was a result of the Liberal cutbacks.
In my province of Saskatchewan we see as well the cutbacks that have occurred. We are dealing with a terrible deficit situation created by the cohorts of the Conservative Party, Premier Grant Devine and his Tories. There is a terrible deficit situation. We are paying hundreds of millions of dollars every year just on the interest on the debt that Mr. Devine and the Tories out there have left us. The federal cutbacks to the EPF have resulted in the loss to the province of Saskatchewan of $1.19 billion since the 1982-83 cutbacks introduced by the Liberals.
We see and hear both government and Liberal members shed crocodile tears about medicare, yet they are responsible for the cutbacks in EPF and medicare is under threat because of these cutbacks.
Private Members' Business
Since the days of Pierre Trudeau the federal government has consistently off-loaded to the provinces. I am all in favour of entrenching the rights to basic health services as well as education, housing, food, et cetera, to all Canadians and having that in the Constitution.
In fact, during the Constitution debates in the early 1980s I proposed that my party should have stood up and insisted on a social charter. What we had from Mr. Trudeau at the time was a 19th century Liberal constitutional document. I felt we should have moved forward and insisted on a 20th century document that had as well some collective rights.
There is no sense in entrenching a social charter in the Constitution unless there is a guarantee in the Constitution that no future federal governments can unilaterally change programs like the EPF program. I fail to hear the Liberals talk about that.
We can entrench anything in the Constitution but if there is no financial means to enforce it, we will see as we have seen the slow erosion of medicare. If we are going to entrench a social charter and things like medicare in the Constitution, we must insist and the provinces will insist that programs like the EPF are guaranteed, that no future Liberal or Tory government can unilaterally change those legal agreements. Then we might have a chance of preserving medicare.
Canadian people watching the proceedings today should not be fooled by the Liberals' crocodile tears over medicare. They are as much responsible as this present Tory administration for the erosion of medicare in this country.
I am sure the Canadian people will recognize that what Pierre Trudeau did in the early eighties set in motion the slow erosion of medical services right across this country. I am sure the Canadian public has not forgotten.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to begin by congratulating my friend, the member for Mississauga East, for presenting this extremely important motion to the House of Commons.
I could not help but notice that the member for Regina-Qu'Appelle was made extremely nervous by her presentation. Perhaps it comes as a result of the fact that the three provincial NDP governments that are

Private Members' Business
participating in the present constitutional talks have really not been very active in this particular area.
Once again, I would like to thank the member for Mississauga East for realizing that this is truly a Canadian issue.
This debate is very timely since the preliminary constitutional talks are approaching their conclusion and the issue of what is to be included in the final text is the subject of serious discussion at the moment. I support my friend's demand that the protection of our health care system should be included in the Constitution.
Canadians are rightly supportive of medicare. Given recent calls for the introduction of user fees and other measures, the need to maintain the integrity of our social programs is urgent.
I know that as a member of the Beaudoin-Dobbie committee my colleague heard from numerous witnesses about the need to maintain all aspects of our medicare system. The commitment of all Liberals to a strong health care system was evident in the dissenting opinions expressed on this issue by the Liberal members in the committee's final report. I quote: "The Liberal members believe that the protection of health care is so fundamental to Canadians that they recommend that the Constitution enshrine not only a commitment but an obligation of governments to provide universal publicly-funded hospital and medical care to all citizens".
That is the difference between members of the Liberal Party and members of the Progressive Conservative government and the New Democratic Party. That strong recommendation is a clear example of my party's dedication to safeguarding Canada's health care system.
The most recent demonstration of this commitment came two weeks ago in Regina when our leader spoke out strongly on the issue.
During his speech he pledged that under a Liberal government Canadians would be guaranteed the health care they need when they need it. In a very clear manner he reaffirmed the principles that have made our health care system the envy of the world.
A Liberal government would protect the universality, the portability, the comprehensiveness, the accessibility and the public administration of medicare.
Those five principles are the foundation upon which the whole system stands. Compromise one, and the whole structure is weakened.
That is the message that the Liberal Party is sending to the advocates of user fees and other quick-fix solutions. User fees are not the answer. The system cannot be repaired by attacking those least able to pay. Users fees contradict a basic philosophical principle of our health care system which is the care for everyone, especially those who cannot afford treatment.
Instead of instant non-solutions the Liberal Party is calling for solutions that respond to the concerns of Canadians. It is necessary to examine the system to find innovative ways to provide the same quality of care that Canadians are used to without sacrificing those five principles.
There are many ways in which the medicare system could be reformed to make it more efficient and more responsive to the needs of the community.
We should look into whether or not medicare pays for unnecessary tests or medication. One medical expert estimated that hundreds of millions of dollars are wasted every year on unnecessary drugs for senior citizens.
We could also examine how we use our hospitals. Could some basic fundamental problems be handled by community health clinics instead of hospital emergency rooms? Would the elderly and the disabled be better served if they could live at home instead of in a hospital?
What Canada needs is not user fees for medical care but a greater emphasis placed on home-care programs and local clinics. They could lighten the loads with which our hospitals are presently struggling.
Community based services such as those are the way of the future. A greater degree of community involvement is called for. In recent years, governments have demonstrated they no longer have the ability to provide for the needs of citizens. By using a more co-operative approach, governments would be able to use their consid-
June 8, 1992

erable power to help redistribute and co-ordinate services and improve on how they are delivered.
Obviously, there is some resistance to the idea of decentralizing the provision of services. The resistance must be overcome because the time for radical reform of Canada's health care system is fast approaching.
Canada's population is aging and it is aging rapidly. In 1986 young people made up 26 per cent of Canada's population and the elderly only 11 per cent. By the year 2020, it is expected that the relative share of these two groups will be identical at 19 per cent. This is of particular concern to young Canadians who have the responsibility to care for the elderly. It should also be of great concern to everyone in this Chamber. We all require care and the existing system, unless it is changed, may not be able to provide this care 20 years from now.
Now is the time to make the necessary changes. We must do so in order to maintain the high level of service that Canadians now enjoy as well as to prepare for the needs of the future.
We in the Liberal Party realize that the system must be reformed but we also know that the reform must not come at the expense of the five principles our leader outlined in Regina.
Our health care system is the cornerstone of the ideals of the compassionate society Canadians have built for themselves. It is one of those principal elements that makes Canada a great nation in which to live. At the foundation of that system is its generous spirit. It takes care of all Canadians regardless of where they live, how they live or how much they earn.
Some people are now threatening to undermine this system. They are camouflaging their attempts with claims that they can no longer afford to be generous. I say to them that when we can no longer afford to care for the sick, Canada will cease to be the Canada of which I have spoken. To strike a blow against medicare is to strike at the very heart of this great nation.
Before tearing down a structure that so many other people look upon with envy, I would suggest that the apostles of privatization should look at the United States of America, a nation often used as a model. In the United States, the only industrialized country without a comprehensive government health care program, there
Government Orders
is increasing pressure to introduce the kind of system that we have in Canada.
I am sure that eventually the supporters of user fees will realize how misguided they are. I am confident they will understand that our health care system requires a general overhaul, not a fine tuning.
In conclusion, we must protect medicare. That is why we should enshrine that protection in the Constitution. That is why this House should act on the motion presented by the member for Mississauga East.

On a point of order, Mr. Speaker, with the kind indulgence of the House, I would like to ask for the unanimous consent of the House at this time to place before it two amendments that I believe have been circulated to the Table, or at least the Liberal Whip and House leader and the government House leader or Whip. That was my understanding at least.
The fact of these motions not being before the House in the proper fashion at this point is entirely my fault for which I do apologize and take full responsibility. If, however, having understood that, the House could find it in its heart to be indulgent in this instance, I would be most grateful.

Mr. Speaker, I welcome the opportunity that is occasioned by your ruling to speak to my amendments as they have been grouped for debate and to the thrust and the substance of those amendments.
I would like to remind the House that Bill C-41, the energy efficiency act, is a bill to primarily set minimum energy efficiency standards for a variety of residential energy using products such as fridges, stoves, washers and driers, and household appliances of that nature.
This bill was discussed in committee. I might add that the discussion in committee was very favourable. There was a wide degree of consensus among all parties in committee as to the thrust and the importance of this legislation. In fact, members of the committee generally supported extending the scope and the meaning of the legislation into other areas. There was general support
June 8, 1992

for that even from the minister of energy when he appeared before the committee as a witness.
We support the thrust of this legislation on this side of the House although we have problems with some of the particular aspects of it. My amendment addresses a very specific deficiency in that legislation, something which was omitted. I believe my amendment is timely, given the discussions which are currently taking place on the environment in Rio de Janiero this week.
Bill C-41 restricts the interprovincial trade and movement across provinces of products that do not meet the energy efficiency standards provided as regulations to this bill. It also prevents the importation of products which do not meet those standards.
What the bill does not do is this. It does not address the issue of the export by Canada of products which do not meet the minimum energy standards which we will require in Canada should this legislation become law. In fact, if we look at clause 4 of this bill, it says:
4.(1) No dealer shall, for the purpose of sale or lease, ship an
energy-using product from the province in which it was manufactured
to another province, or import an energy-using product into Canada,
unless
(a)	the product complies with the energy efficiency standard; and
(b)	the product or its package is labelled in a prescribed form or manner, if any.
The other clauses that my amendment addresses would simply add export to the other provisions in clause 4 and the other related clause.
What my amendment does is require Canada to extend to other countries the same rigorous standards which we would want to apply to ourselves concerning the use of energy efficiency standards, and by extension the emission of greenhouse gases that are produced in the process of producing that energy.
My amendment would extend this discipline to other countries; the discipline we are requiring ourselves to abide by using these amendments.
We can ask the first question as to who would be affected by this amendment. If we look at the exports of these types of appliances by Canada, we would see using the 1990 trade statistics for major appliances of this kind that there were $153.5 million worth. Of that, the bulk or 82 per cent of those exports were to the United States,
Government Orders
which already has higher energy efficiency standards than we have in Canada.
The remainder of those exports would currently be 4 per cent to Europe, 7 per cent to Asia, and another 7 per cent to other countries. There is a small portion of our exports that would potentially be affected by this legislation according to these statistics.
The amendment I propose, if it is restrictive in any way to those manufacturers of these products outside of the United States, would be to a very limited degree at the present time. However, that does not deny the importance of the amendment because essentially what this amendment would do would be to require Canada to set its standards in its exports to other countries, standards that it is maintaining for itself.
For that reason it would create a signal to the international community in a very small but important sense that we are prepared to practice what we preach internally in respect of our trade to other countries.
We would be saying with these amendments that we will not export inferior products from an energy standpoint to, for example, a country that could potentially be in the future a very large consumer of these products. We would provide products in those countries that meet an energy efficiency standard. That is what this amendment would do.
I realize we are dealing with, in a sense, a policy dilemma here. The dilemma we face is whether or not we should apply our standards to other countries concerning the environment or energy efficiency in this case.
The debate being brought forward at this time is that we in Canada proclaim our adherence and this government proclaims its adherence to the importance of concern for the environment and the desire to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The desire is to set an example in terms of energy efficiency, an example that it is willing to impose not only on itself but also in its relationship with other countries.
There is an additional reason for the time limits of an amendment of this kind and for having this subject brought forward for debate. We are currently in the midst of the Uruguay round of GATT negotiations. Although the environment has not been a factor in world trade discussions, clearly the environment is going to be a factor in future trade discussions on an international basis and the way in which trade law develops. It is

Government Orders
through the application of smaller agreements and legislation which sets that pattern in various countries.
Clearly this type of amendment sets the tone for the future conduct in Canada of its trade relations with other countries, it says in effect that we will apply to our trade law or to the aspects of our legislation that affect our trade the kind of concern for the environment that we want to impose upon ourselves. That is the point behind that particular amendment to this piece of legislation and why I am bringing it forward today.

Veiy briefly on the amendment put in by my colleague, Bill C-41 was generally a Canadian market and Canadian consumer piece of legislation. We believe that the compliance and monitoring activities of this bill as included over the next two years in this piece of legislation when it becomes law and that the international trade policies and practices can certainly be looked at at that time.
At this point the government is not prepared to support these amendments. We certainly understand that the member has done some good work in this, but we believe that the actions of the next two years and the direction of the government and of the energy policies and practices will be that which will allow for monitoring over the next two years on the activities of the piece of legislation.

Mr. Speaker, just very briefly, the reason that the bill was brought forward, the reason we are discussing this today, is that it is widely and generally recognized that conservation and increased energy efficiencies are absolutely crucial to the reduction of energy use generally upon which the fate of the planet may hang.
In applauding the government for bringing the bill forward, for making this small but nonetheless important first step, I would like as well to applaud the member for Cape Breton Highlands-Canso for bringing forward his amendments today. I think James Shaver Woodsworth said it as well as anyone could in his Grace Before Meat "What we desire for ourselves, we wish for all".
What that means, very simply, in terms of this bill is that which we wish to achieve in our domestic market in terms of the increased energy efficiencies that we hope the bill will foster, and in fact we know the bill will at some point require, those efficiencies should not be restrained to our domestic market, but rather where we have international customers we should as well grace them with those efficiencies.
There is no reason of which I can think to vote against these amendments on their principle. On the face of it there is no cause that I can see for continuing to allow the export of domestically produced, or imported and reproduced, goods to other countries, presumably in the Third World, of an efficiency lower than those which we would tolerate in our own country. In a sense, Mr. Speaker, that is a sort of conceptual insult to those countries.
I would strongly support these motions and would urge the government to reconsider, if not today then as the parliamentary secretary held out the hope, perhaps in the near future.

Mr. Speaker, the goal of both amendments-I will speak of both of them together-is to lend further market effect to the bill.

In the first instance the amendment would have the effect of requiring that advertising of energy products include the information that the bill now requires be included in the labelling of the products. All this means is that the information, on the basis of which we hope consumers will make informed choices in favour of greater energy efficiency, will be available to consumers before they go to the shop floor. In other words, in reading the flyers that come in the mailbox or the advertisements in the Friday newspaper consumers will at that point be informed as to the relative energy efficiency merits of the product under consideration.
The reason for this was pointed out in testimony before the committee: most consumers, by the time they hit the shop floor, have narrowed down at the very least their range of potential products and often that range will be further narrowed by what is available in the store. If they have available to them ahead of time those crucial pieces of energy efficiency information, they will be able to make not only better informed but more effective choices before they ever leave their homes. That is the point of the first amendment.
The second amendment would be to require that the information presented both in the labelling of the device and in the advertising, if the first amendment carries, would be put at least in part in terms of anticipated cost savings. In other words dollars expressed on whatever basis and in whatever form the government chooses but nonetheless a presentation in terms of dollars. Brian Kelly, president of Marbek Resources, in his testimony before the legislative committee noted that dollars were the official language of Canadian consumers. We are not suggesting in this amendment that information like kilowatt hours per year be excluded from the label. Certainly that information is valuable and can be included. We are saying, as is the case in Jamaica, for example, that dollars be included on whatever base the minister or the Governor in Council may choose.
Both these amendments, therefore, are an attempt through the closer informing of consumers to give greater impact and greater effect to the principles of the bill. As such I would hope they would enjoy the support of the House.
