subtopic: AN ACT TO AMEND CERTAIN ACTS WITH RESPECT TO PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES MEASURE TO AMEND
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I rise today to speak on Bill C-78, an omnibus bill to amend certain acts with respect to persons with disabilities.
The changes contained in this omnibus bill have been welcomed by persons with disabilities. They are certainly long overdue. However, the bad news is that there are so many important things not included in the bill, so many things that persons with disabilities have been expecting for a very long time.
I have seen first hand how much these legislative improvements are needed. I have travelled from coast to coast to meet with groups and individuals in their communities. I have heard and seen some appalling situations. I have come to realize how much it really matters that we get serious about these problems.

It seems to me that what we are currently saying to many persons with disabilities is that we do not want them to play a full and active role in society. I think, for example, of the disabled person who has significant disability related expenses. If that person somehow against all odds manages to get some training and to find a job, he may find that the government immediately cuts off the financial support it previously offered. He may find that he cannot really afford to work.
In effect we are saying to that person: "We don't want you to be a proud, independent, productive Canadian citizen". Unfortunately we have a system that is full of disincentives.
I want to relate a few examples of some of the cases I have seen or heard about across Canada. I can remember when the Liberal task force on disabled persons was in New Brunswick. I met an elderly woman who lived some distance outside Fredericton. She had serious eye problems and needed to see an eye specialist regularly. She could not drive and because the government had cut VIA Rail services to Fredericton there was simply no way for her to visit her eye doctor.
I have heard cases of persons in wheelchairs who made plane reservations weeks in advance, told the airline about the wheelchair, showed up in advance at the airport, and then were told by the pilot at the very last minute that they could not board the plane. Our laws currently give pilots the authority to do that.
Some of the most disturbing stories I heard came from isolated aboriginal communities. For example, persons with disabilities often need to see medical specialists who are located only in major urban centres many thousands of miles away. They told me horrendous stories of regularly having to travel vast distances to receive care.
These are the people who are looking forward to major improvements in long awaited omnibus legislation. I do not think there is any doubt they are deeply disappointed by this legislation.
I would like to quote Mr. Jim Dirksen, president of the Canadian Disability Rights Council, who said: "If this bill were all we were going to get, we would have to register tremendous disappointment". Mr. Dirksen compared the bill to a sod-turning ceremony which is more a commitment to build something rather than substantive changes on the ground.
Government Orders
I would also like to quote from an article on disability issues that appeared in The Toronto Star on May 21. The article is entitled "Government turns its back on disabled". It examines in considerable detail how this government has neglected Canadians with disabilities. This is how this omnibus bill is described in the article: "Sweeping changes were called for by the disabled community. Elaborate promises were made by the government but the law itself is a joke. The government failed to deliver. Nobody takes it seriously".
Finally I want to quote from an editorial that appeared in The Ottawa Citizen on May 23. Again, this editorial outlines how the government has disappointed disabled persons in Canada. It described the omnibus bill as pathetic and as a pale and sickly shadow of the draft bill produced by the Canadian Disability Rights Council. It says the bill is a far cry from the American's disability act that went into effect in the United States in January.
These are not exactly glowing endorsements of this bill. They are fair reflections of what disabled persons feel about it. It is simply lacking in substance.
The government made a number of related announcements at the time this bill was first tabled. These announcements were promises of further action on disability issues to be taken at some unspecified time in the future after further review and consultation.
All of us in this House realize that the words further review and consultation are code words for delay or inaction.
Last fall the Canadian Disability Rights Council presented to the government a 107-page brief outlining in veiy specific terms the legislative reforms it hoped to see in an omnibus bill. The brief even included draft legislation for such a bill. I will be quoting from this bill today in my remarks because it illustrates so well the huge gap between what disabled persons were expecting in this bill and what they actually got.
This brief represents a lot of work on the part of this group and I want to congratulate the council on the good job it has done. Many other groups have made similar briefs and presentations to the government in recent years. This is one reason why persons with disabilities are so disappointed with this bill. It was the government that funded the Canadian Disability Rights Council to prepare this brief. This was seen as an act of good faith in the community. Naturally there was an expectation that

June 8, 1992
Government Orders
the government would follow through with substantive changes.
Perhaps the process resulted in unrealistic expectations. I am not sure if there is a better way of doing it. All I know is that a lot of people are very, very disappointed and I do not blame them.
Before I move on a specific discussion of the act, I want to make a few comments about persons with disabilities in Canada. We know now that there are between three and four million Canadians living with some kind of disability. That is well over 10 per cent of our total population. This is not a small group of people we are talking about. Many of these disabled persons are seniors. If we think about it we can all think of a senior we know who has difficulty seeing, hearing or walking. It may be a parent, a grandparent, a friend or a neighbour.
I would ask hon. members to remember that many of us will have to deal with these disabilities ourselves someday.
Many of these people with disabilities live in poverty in a country that prides itself on its standard of living and its commitments to human rights. Women with disabilities are particularly disadvantaged, earning on average less than half of what disabled men earn. They are even more likely than non-disabled women to suffer sexual and physical abuse.
As well, aboriginals with disabilities are much more likely to live in poverty than other Canadians with disabilities.
I hope that all members would agree that it is the responsibility of the government that all Canadians have equal rights regardless of abilities.
The most substantive amendments in this act are changes to the Canada Elections Act. I suspect that the government is more aware of these issues because of the $18 million royal commission on electoral reform which made a number of recommendations in this area. Presumably the all-party committee looking at the royal commission may have been planning similar amendments. Anyway, it is good to see this increased awareness.
Bill C-78 contains a number of amendments to ensure that persons with disabilities are able to exercise their rights to participate in elections. I am sure all members of the House would agree that the right to vote is one of the most fundamental and important rights that we enjoy in a democracy. It is a right that most of us take for granted but we would not take it for granted if we were blind or in a wheelchair. For many disabled persons in the past, voting has been so difficult that they have been unable to exercise their democratic rights.
Among other amendments, this bill contains changes to ensure that polling stations will have level access, that disabled persons may receive assistance in the voting booth and that special measures will be taken to assist disabled voters living in institutions. These are all welcomed changes.
I would also like to point out that we have a responsibility to assist not only the disabled voters but also disabled candidates because the right to run for public office is an important democratic right.
Bill C-78 takes into account the special financial expenses of disabled candidates that relate to then-disabilities. These expenses will no longer need to be claimed as election expenses. The effect of this change is to remove an obviously discriminatory requirement from the election financing laws.
We only need to look at legislatures across the country to see that we have had a relatively low number of disabled candidates in Canada in spite of the fact that more than 10 per cent of Canadians are disabled persons.
The Canadian Disability Rights Council has recommended that the government should reimburse disabled candidates for any special personal expenses related to their disabilities and in this way encourage disabled candidates to run for office.
I would also point out that it is not only the government that has responsibility in this area. All political parties also have a responsibility to ensure that disabled persons are encouraged to run as candidates.
June 8, 1992

There are a number of other issues related to disabled persons in the Canadian Elections Act which were not addressed by this bill. Our party is hoping that some of these issues will be addressed by the parliamentary committee examining the recommendations of the royal commission on electoral reform.
I am pleased to see that the government has introduced amendments to the Access to Information Act and the Privacy Act so that people with disabilities are able to request information in alternate formats. This applies to people with sensory disabilities, that is, disabilities of sight and hearing. The alternate formats could be large print, Braille or audio cassette.
I am concerned about some aspects of these amendments. For example, the amendment allows the head of government departments to determine whether a request for alternative formats is both necessary and reasonable. I am concerned about the extent to which this may limit the rights of access for disabled persons.
Improvement to these acts are necessary because Treasury Board guidelines on alternate formats have been virtually ignored by many departments. Treasury Board has previously directed all departments to set aside a fixed percentage of their publicity and information budgets for producing materials in alternate formats.
However, according to the Canadian Disability Rights Council: "The reality is that few departments have adhered to this guideline. Recent surveys conducted by the National Library of Canada and the Canadian Human Rights Commission show that little action to encourage or require compliance has been taken by the Treasury Board and that very few departments have produced or are about to produce documents in alternate format".
This shows a rather callous disregard for the rights of disabled persons. I would certainly hope that this legislative change will help produce a change in attitudes in government departments.
I was also pleased to see that the bill contains an important change to the Criminal Code related to the rights of disabled persons in court. Changes to the code will allow a complainant with a disability to give evidence regarding certain sexual offences from behind a screen or outside the courtroom.
Government Orders
This will only occur in cases in which seeing the accused would prevent the complainant from testifying freely.
This measure is extremely important for disabled persons but it falls far short of what they were looking for. When we think about the circumstances in which many disabled persons live, we can clearly see that they are among the most vulnerable people in our society. There is great potential for abuse, for assault and sexual assault. The government has indicated that the Minister of Justice will review other sections of the Criminal Code and the Canadian Evidence Act which have been identified by the disabled community as requiring attention.
Again, we have to wonder why the need for further review. The disability community has outlined the problems very clearly and has made some very specific recommendations to address the problems.
According to the Canadian Disability Rights Council, disabled persons are up to 10 times more likely to be assaulted and sexually assaulted than people without disabilities. Often the abuser is not charged because of the difficulties associated with the disabled person's testifying in court. The result is that people who assault or sexually assault these vulnerable people in our society are getting away with their despicable crimes. It is no wonder that disabled persons have been so anxious for the legislative amendments required to change the status quo.
Unfortunately, this bill omits a number of important recommendations made by the Canadian Disability Rights Council in this area. For example, the council has recommended an exception to the hearsay rule that would allow a third party, such as an attendant, to give evidence instead of the victim where no other way exists to get the evidence in court. As well, we need to be taking advantage of the technology that allows a blind and visually impaired person to identify the accused through the use of voice line-ups. Disabled persons want the current provisions in the Criminal Code that deal with abuse by those in positions of trust and authority to be extended to include protection for persons with disabilities.
When you think about these problems you realize that some of them have been with us for a very, very long time. It is sad indeed that we have not yet been able to devise innovative ways of overcoming these problems in order to ensure greater fairness to people with disabili-

June 8, 1992
Government Orders
ties. They are entitled to the same legal rights and the same protection under the law as everyone else.
One of the most important areas for persons with disabilities in Canada today is that of access to transportation. That is no surprise when we think about it. Access to transportation is a vitally important element of life in the modem world. It is something that most of us take for granted, something that enables us to accomplish the things we do every day. Without it we simply could not participate fully in the work world and in community life. I can assure members of the House that over the past year or so I have heard some real horror stories about the difficulties people with disabilities often encounter when they want to travel by plane or bus, for example.
For those of us who travel routinely without these kinds of problems it is hard to imagine what it must be like to put up with such frustrating experiences. Bill C-78 makes only one change to the National Transportation Act. It is a change adding the words "access to persons with disabilities" to the preamble of the act as part of the preamble's over-all description of Canada's transportation system. Again, there is no time frame, no deadlines, no specific details.
The government also indicated that the specific recommendations of the Canadian Disability Rights Council will be considered as a part of a review of the National Transportation Act to be completed next year. Next year; again there will be more delay. This change to the preamble is of course welcome but again it falls far short of expectations. There seems to be little doubt that the transportation companies will continue to delay efforts to ensure access for as long as they can get away with it.
I recognize that removing barriers to access does cost money, but at some point the government has to bite the bullet, show that it is serious about access and impose some comprehensive deadlines and mechanisms to ensure the enforcement of access regulations and requirements. That is what is noticeably absent from this legislation. It is not more fancy words that disabled persons are looking for. It is action and results.
I have mentioned some of the problems that disabled persons encounter when travelling by plane.
I also want to mention the particular problems associated with bus travel. According to the Canadian Disability Rights Council, the bus industry has taken advantage of the confusion about which level of government has jurisdiction over it to escape regulating access altogether. Yet the bus is a key connector between towns and the rural communities. Buses provide services to places that trains and planes do not.
It seems to me that in the face of jurisdictional confusion, it is up to the federal government to show leadership and to ensure that the rights of disabled travellers are not overlooked.
The technology to make buses wheelchair accessible has been available for a long time.
I also want to point out that in the areas of accessible bus travel Canada lags far behind other countries. For example, the United States department of transportation recently announced that all new intercity buses purchased after 1993 must be fully accessible. Many of these buses are made in Winnipeg. The accessible buses are sold to the United States. The non-accessible buses are sold in Canada.
I have heard that because the United States is so far ahead of Canada when it comes to accessible buses, there is a real fear that the Americans will dump then-old inaccessible buses in Canada after 1993.1 find that a real embarrassment for our country.
These measures being enacted in the United States are the kinds of measures that disabled persons in Canada have been demanding for years. These are the kinds of measures they expected to see in the omnibus bill or in an announcement that accompanied the bill. They were not expecting to hear they Mil have to wait until next year, the year after, or the year after that.
Finally, I want to comment about some of the important issues that should have been addressed in this legislation but have been left out entirely for reasons that are far from clear to me.
One of these is broadcasting and particularly access to television. This bill contains no amendments to the Broadcasting Act despite the recommendations of the disability rights advocates.
Statistics Canada tells us that there are 260,000 deaf people in Canada and more than 1.5 million who are
June 8, 1992

hard of hearing. For quite some time we have had the technology to make television accessible to persons with hearing difficulties.
There are several different options but the preferred method is called closed captioning. Closed captioning means that subtitles appear on television screens equipped with special decoder boxes.
I want to mention that it is possible to have a decoder chip built into the television and this costs the manufacturer about five cents. This would save the consumer from having to spend anywhere from $80 to $200 for a decoder box.
In the United States, legislation requires manufacturers to include these chips in televisions. Without legislation businesses will be reluctant to include the chip because often, the same companies that sell televisions also sell decoder boxes. Naturally, they would prefer to make extra money on the sale of decoder boxes. Sadly, we have seen no move toward this kind of legislation in Canada.
I also want to point out that captioning is not only essential for deaf people, but it is also useful for people who are learning how to read, or people who are learning a second language.
Unfortunately, broadcasters in Canada have been very slow to provide captioned programs. Last year it is estimated that only 10 per cent to 15 per cent of programs in both public and private stations were captioned. Recent licence renewals for both the CBC and CTV networks provided for only 15 hours of captioned programs per week.
The CRTC has refused to require complete access for the hard-of-hearing as a condition of licence. What the disabled community expects is nothing less than 100 per cent captioning for all programs.
Again, I want to stress that this is not a small audience we are talking about. It is 1.5 million Canadians. These are Canadians who pay taxes just like the rest of us including taxes for the CBC. They expect to be able to watch television just like the rest of us. Will they get a tax rebate if they cannot understand the programming?
It has become very clear that it is not good enough to encourage broadcasters to provide closed captioning.
Government Orders
This voluntary approach has brought very disappointing results. The time has obviously come for the government to impose requirements and deadlines.
The government has announced that the Minister of Communications will be directing the CRTC in the areas of captioning and employment equity after further consultation with the disabled community and broadcasters.
Again, we have no specifics, no timetables and still more consultation. I am all for consultation but in this case it is quite obvious what the disabled community wants. It is equally obvious that broadcasters will attempt to do as little as possible because of the expense involved. We can only hope that the minister and the CRTC will regard this matter with the same urgency as the disabled community.
I could go on and on about all the issues that have not been addressed in this bill and all the amendments that have not been included.
As I have mentioned, disabled persons are disappointed that the bill contains no amendments to the Broadcasting Act, the Immigration Act or the Canada Evidence Act. Persons with disabilities also consider improvements to the Employment Equity Act a high priority. They are also looking for improvements to the Canadian Human Rights Act, the National Training Act, the Income Tax Act, the National Housing Act, Canada Assistance Plan Act, Vocational Rehabilitation of Disabled Persons Act, the Canada Pension Plan Act and the Canada Labour Code, among others.
The questions that disabled persons are asking now are: why the delay? Why is there a need for still more review and consultation? These are definitely not new issues.
There has in fact been extensive consultation with the disabled community. The community's recommendations have been quite specific and thoroughly researched. The government has had years and years to prepare this legislation. Why is it so skimpy? Why are there so many important issues not addressed in this bill?
Many of these issues were raised long ago. In 1981, the Obstacles report of the Standing Committee on Human Rights and the Status of Disabled Persons, chaired by the Hon. David Smith, made 130 recommendations that touched on every aspect of the social, economic and legal

Government Orders
situation of disabled persons. More than 10 years later, many of these recommendations remain unfulfilled.
The feeling of disappointment is one that is all too familiar to disabled Canadians. They have been told time and time again that they will have to wait. They have waited and waited. They are tired of waiting. They are tired of being treated like second-class citizens. They are tired of having to wait for their rights.
We will be supporting Bill C-78. I suppose when you want to walk a mile and you can only go an inch, you have to accept that inch. The disabled community, all those who are friends of the disabled community and those who work with them and those of us in the Liberal Party are hoping that this really is just the sod turning, that within the next few months there will be some positive action.
We ask that the Prime Minister affirm to the disabled community that he will be taking some very positive action further than this omnibus bill in the next few months.

speakeroldname: Hon. Robert de Cotret (Secretary of State of Canada):
speakerposition: Secretary of State of Canada
subtopic: AN ACT TO AMEND CERTAIN ACTS WITH RESPECT TO PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES MEASURE TO AMEND
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as Secretary of State and minister responsible for the status of disabled persons, I was honoured recently to introduce Bill C-78 in the Elouse. It is indeed a pleasure to rise today to participate in this historic debate. It is historic because in debating Bill C-78, Parliament is for the first time ever considering a bill that focuses exclusively on the concerns of the 3.3 million Canadians with disabilities.
The importance of this is worth noting, not only because it is a first, but because prescribing the requirements of equal access in law will have an impact beyond the specific acts being amended.
The provisions of Bill C-78, and the other measures that we have announced, represent a further step forward to the full social and economic integration of persons with disabilities. It is an important step toward ensuring that all of our laws reflect the needs, interests, aspirations and rights of all Canadians, including those with disabilities.
An important feature of the bill and related policy and regulatory actions is the process through which they have become a reality.
My department played a co-ordinating role with the Department of Justice and the other concerned departments in facilitating a close and effective partnership with the disability community. Over the past eight months, the government has worked with the Canadian Disability Rights Council in the development of this bill, and I want to thank them for their leadership, determination and insight.
Another important partner in the development of Bill C-78 was the Standing Committee on Human Rights and the Status of Disabled Persons. It was the Standing Committee, in its 1990 report, A Consensus for Action, that first recommended a review of federal legislation to ensure that Canadians with disabilities are full participants in the social and economic mainstream. The standing committee provides an important forum for the disability community and other stakeholders to clarify outstanding issues and encourage government attention. I thank the members of the standing committee for their continued collaboration.
Bill C-78 is a good example of what can be accomplished when people with a shared vision can work together for a common purpose. In considering the provisions of this unique bill, our common purpose is the full and equal participation of persons with disabilities. We are single-minded in our determination that all citizens, regardless of physical or mental disability, have a right to be full participants in their communities. Surely we can afford nothing less than to benefit from the full contribution of every Canadian.
It was with this vision in mind that in September of 1991, the Prime Minister announced the National Strategy for the Integration of Persons with Disabilities. Under the strategy, the federal government made a commitment to provide access for persons with disabilities, to ensure their integration in the economic life of the country, and to promote their full participation in Canadian society. A comprehensive review of federal legislation was identified as an important element of the National strategy.
June 8, 1992



The measures set out in Bill C-78 are a central part of the government's national strategy and will significantly improve the opportunities for Canadians with disabilities to participate fully in the community.
Bill C-78 and the changes it proposes build on the past legislative achievement in support of equality and full participation of people with disabilities. For example, in 1985 section 15 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms came into effect. Canada is the only country in the world whose Constitution includes a provision designed to protect persons with disabilities against discrimination.
Other significant legislative measures include first, the passage in 1986 of the Employment Equity Act; second, a series of changes to the Income Thx Act to better address the needs of persons with disabilities; and third, amendments made to the National Transportation Act in 1988 to empower the National Transportation Agency to set, administer and enforce accessibility standards for all modes of transportation within the federal jurisdiction.
All of those legislative changes have been made in close consultation with those most concerned, Canadians with disabilities. We have been listening to them and taking concrete action to address their needs and rights.
That is why Bill C-78, in which we are proposing to amend six federal statutes to remove barriers to the full and equal participation of persons with disabilities, is so important.
Citizenship is the key to participation. Bill C-78 proposes to amend the Citizenship Act to ensure that people who have disabilities have equal access to Canadian citizenship. The amendments would remove the word disability from the interpretation section of the act and more descriptive and appropriate wording would be inserted where the term now appears.
It is also proposed that the current ministerial provision to wave the residence requirement for persons with a mental disability be deleted from the act.
The most fundamental of all democratic rights is the right to vote. However, this right is sometimes restricted by factors such as accessibility of polling stations or problems in receiving the kind of assistance required to mark a ballot. Moreover, the freedom to run for public
Government Orders
office is sometimes limited for persons with disabilities. Candidates with disabilities who might require the services of a full-time attendant or sign language interpreters ought not to be disadvantaged as a result of additional costs. The suggested changes to the Canada Elections Act would ensure that people with disabilities can participate fully in the electoral process.
For example, proposed amendments include a requirement that all polling stations and returning offices provide level access. It would also provide the use of mobile polling stations to bring the vote to individuals residing in institutions and clarification of the definition of personal expenses to include additional costs incurred by candidates with disabilities.
Travelling without barriers is one of the most central concerns of people with disabilities. Without accessible transportation, full participation in Canadian life is not possible. For this reason, Bill C-78 proposes to amend the National Transportation Act to directly acknowledge for the first time the importance of accessible transportation. The proposed amendment to the declaratory clause of the act would ensure that our national transportation system meets the needs of travellers with disabilities.
I must add that as part of the statutory review of the National Transportation Act, a review commission was set up to study all aspects of the act and to make recommendations for further changes as required.
Like all citizens, persons with disabilities need to have full access to the justice system. Through proposed amendments to the Criminal Code, Bill C-78 would allow a complainant with a disability to give testimony from behind a screen or outside the courtroom if seeing the accused would prevent the complainant from testifying freely. At the same time, my hon. colleague, the Minister of Justice, is committed to a review of all other proposals put forward by the Canadian Disability Rights Council as part of a larger review of Bill C-15.
The availability of information contributes to an individual's ability to participate. For persons with disabilities, having access to information in an alternative format is critical. The purpose of the Access to Information Act and the Privacy Act is to ensure Canadians, permanent residents and persons present in Canada the right to access personal information and records held by government institutions.

June 8, 1992
Government Orders
Accordingly, Bill C-78 proposes to amend the Access to Information Act and the Privacy Act to establish the circumstances under which access to information covered by the acts will be provided in formats such as Braille, large print and audio cassette.
The proposed amendments would also give persons with disabilities a right to complain to the appropriate commissioner if they have not been given access to a record of information or an alternative format.
Taken together, these proposed statutory changes contained in Bill C-78 will significantly improve the lives of Canadians with disabilities. On a related legislative matter, my colleague, the Minister of Employment and Immigration, will soon introduce amendments to the Immigration Act related to the medical criteria used to screen applicants seeking admission to Canada.
These would address, among other things, the concern of the disabled community that the act currently discriminates on the basis of disability. These changes will be developed through continued consultation with the disabled community.
Our work is not finished. Bill C-78 is a step forward. In fact, the bill underscores the government's commitment to continued collaboration with the disabled community toward further legislative reform.

Our work has not finished with Bill C-78. It is a beginning, a step forward, an important step, but it underscores the government's commitment to continued collaboration with the disabled toward further legislative reform.
In speaking about Bill C-78, Jim Derksen, chairperson of the Canadian Disability Rights Council, used the analogy of a sod turning. Someone has to turn the ground in order to build. Removing the legislative barriers facing persons with disabilities cannot be done overnight. It is a building process. All of us must be involved. Only by working together, as we have in the development of Bill C-78, can meaningful change take place.
We may not change the world by taking these measures. We will, however, create a world that is open to future commitments, future changes, and will have one
more reason to say that Canada is the world leader in ensuring equality and quality of life for its people.
Since tabling Bill C-78 in the House, I have closely followed the discussions of the disabled and have listened to their proposals for amendments to the bill. As well, I received suggestions from the Standing Committee on Human Rights and the Status of Disabled Persons when I appeared before it on June 2.
The recommendations put forward by the disabled and the parliamentary committee, and in particular the hon. member for Beaches-Woodbine, will strengthen those clauses in Bill C-78 dealing with the assistance provided to enable persons with disabilities to exercise the most fundamental of democratic rights, the right to vote.
The proposed amendments will ensure that any elector with a disability will receive the assistance required to mark his or her ballot. The changes will streamline the language in the bill, making it as inclusive as possible.
I am therefore pleased to support a proposal to amend clauses 25, 26, 29, 30 and 31 of Bill C-78 with regard to the Canada Elections Act.

In closing, I think the Chair will find that there is unanimous consent to complete second reading, Committee of the Whole and third reading of Bill C-78 today.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I rise today to speak on Bill C-78.1 must say that in many ways I feel like speaking about what is not in the bill as opposed to what is in the bill.
As I look through this piece of legislation I recognize that almost all of it deals with changes to the Canada Elections Act. In other words, out of about a 15-page act, less than five of those pages deal with any legislation other than the Canada Elections Act. Unfortunately that symbolizes the problems that exist with the bill. The government, in its desire to be seen as doing something for the disabled community of Canada, decided to do a
June 8, 1992

lot with regard to the Canada Elections Act but did very little in other areas of concern.
It is ironic that this piece of legislation spends so much of its time dealing with the Canada Elections Act and the amendments that the minister is about to make when we go to Committee of the Whole. They are strictly on the Canada Elections Act and are being done at the same time that we have a committee which I also serve on, a special committee which is dealing with the Canada Elections Act.
In one room later today we have a committee that will be discussing the Canada Elections Act. At the same time we have this bill, which is supposed to be concerned with a whole number of concerns that the disabled community has, being dealt with in the House. Those two items are being dealt with in isolation to each other.
We have one bill which deals with the Canada Elections Act, we have a committee which deals with the Canada Elections Act, and unfortunately the two have not been married and there has not been very much consultation between the committee and those clauses that are in the bill and those amendments that the minister just spoke of which he will be making later on this day.
It is unfortunate that this bill is so restricted. As I have checked the history of this legislation, it is not what the disabled community has asked for. Over two years ago the idea of omnibus legislation was presented to the Standing Committee on Human Rights and the Status of Disabled Persons. A coalition of disabled groups, including the Canadian Association for Community Living, the Coalition of Provincial Organizations of the Handicapped and the Canadian Disabilities Rights Council, made that presentation.
The earliest version of the proposal included a real effort to make the laws of Canada reflect the spirit of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms. This first version of omnibus legislation that was produced by the disabled community proposed changes to the Canadian Human Rights Act, the Broadcasting Act, the Copyright Act, the Access to Information Act, the National Transportation Act, the Immigration Act, the Canada Elec-
Govemment Orders
tions Act, the Public Service Employment Act, the Employment Equity Act, the Canada Evidence Act, the Criminal Code of Canada and the Income Ihx Act.
In terms of action to complement legislative change, the disability coalition pointed out that the administration of such programs as the Canada Assistance Plan, the Vocational Rehabilitation for Disabled Persons program and the Established Program Financing, which authorizes federal-provincial activities, results in administrative measures that create impediments to the equality of persons with disabilities.
In addition, the federal government has delegated its authority in certain instances, such as interprovincial bus transportation, in which administrative bodies are not required to ensure the accessibility for disabled persons.
As I mentioned, two years ago this initiative for legislation had finally come from the community itself. This was late in the game, many, many years after the charter had come into effect. Why did it take so long for the government to begin to address the issue of inclusion of people with disabilities?
The New Democratic Party has long supported the inclusion of people with disabilities in all aspects of Canadian society, especially in our laws.
For too long the concerns of people with disabilities have been treated as add-ons to government programs and to laws. This means that their concerns have been treated as special rather than as a fundamental part of the legal and governmental system.
Whenever people are given this type of special treatment it can be seen as a favour and once granted it can also be taken away. That is not the approach that we would advocate.
For over 10 years my colleague, the member for Beaches-Woodbine, has worked on this very issue. When the Liberals were in government and when the Conservatives were in government he was our representative on the various committees that we had, including the special committee on the disabled and the handicapped which in its obstacles report made over 130 recommendations to include the concerns of people with

June 8, 1992
Government Orders
disabilities in the fabric of government policies, pro- Unfortunately, clauses like the one in the Immigration grams and laws.	Act which I referred to help perpetuate that myth.
The member for Beaches-Woodbine participated actively in the parliamentary discussions around the adoption of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms to make certain that people with disabilities were guaranteed equality in section 15 of the charter. Currently, as a member of the Standing Committee on Human Rights and the Status of Disabled Persons, he works constructively with the government and with the Official Opposition to promote this progress.
For those people like the member for Beaches- Woodbine who are concerned with this legislation and for the disabled community there is a great sense of disappointment. Instead of the comprehensive list of legislation that was asked for in front of the committee and that the committee proposed to this House two years ago, the government has presented a very modest list of amendments to a very few acts of Parliament.
As I said earlier, if you take away changes to the Canada Elections Act there is not much left in this legislation.
Our party cannot understand why the minister was unable to include changes to the Immigration Act that the community wanted. Why is section 19(1) of the act not included in this bill? It would send a signal to all Canadians if this section of the Immigration Act were repealed because it prevents most persons with disabilities from getting landed immigrant status and from entering Canada.
According to the Disabled Rights Organization, this provision alone serves to perpetuate the misconceptions and misunderstandings about the abilities of disabled persons.
If I can add a personal note to this intervention, I know, as a former classroom teacher and a member of Parliament for 13 years, it has been that constant communication from the disabled groups within our country that has certainly educated me in terms of their ability to serve and participate in our nation. All too often there is a perception in the public arena that these people must be excluded for their own protection, that these people are not able to participate and that they would be taken advantage of.
We would like to see this act amended. We would like to see the government commit itself to some long-term, major changes to federal government laws and regulations as they affect the disabled.
We have been asked by the disabled groups to help the passage of this legislation through the House to ensure that it is passed today, but these same groups have also said that this is basically the first step, the first move in dealing with legislation that is required. In other words, they have been promised that a second piece of legislation would be coming down later that would deal with the more substantive concerns.
I always get nervous when I hear that because I have often heard governments make that type of promise, especially when their mandate is about to expire. It is very easy to move on a piece of legislation now which is very limited in scope and say we will deal with the major items one, two, three years down the road. Unfortunately history will tell us that in this House of Commons those second pieces of legislation often never appear on our Order Paper, or if they appear on the Order Paper at all it is just prior to an election and they are not passed.
I share the concern of the disabled communities when they say that they need some guarantee from the minister as to when that legislation will be tabled and when the government expects to proceed with it to ensure that it is passed before the next federal election.
Again, the minister referred to regulations when we all know that when there are changes to legislation, it is the regulations that follow and that quite often are the mechanism which make the legislation work.
When will those regulations be brought into place? When will they actually exist? Is it going to be one year, two years or three years from now? Again, why can the government not make a commitment to ensure that those regulations will be put in place and give the people, especially the disabled communities, a firm deadline as to when that would happen?
We have a lot of concerns with regard to the legislation. We are concerned especially with regard to the fact that so many areas were not dealt with. Earlier I read
June 8, 1992

Government Orders
from a list of legislation that the disabled communities society that suffer, unfortunately, from discrimination wanted amended. It is not dealt with in this legislation, and inequality.
There are a number of other concerns as well that I would like to put into the record at this time. They include the fact that changes to the Access to Information and to the Privacy Act would mean that fees for people with disabilities which other Canadians do not have to pay would be required in order for disabled people to use that legislation effectively.
We are concerned with the exclusion of senior citizens from the changes to the Criminal Code. We are concerned with the fact that the closed captioning which we are used to seeing with our television sets will be dealt with by cabinet order to the CRTC rather than being brought forward as part of changes to the Broadcasting Act. Government will do this in isolation with no public input and with no discussion through the House of Commons as legislation is being passed.
On the government's failure to follow through on previous commitments, the Minister of Transport promised that if the provinces did not make intercity buses accessible, the federal government would intervene. It has not done so. The government failed in the proposed amendments to the National Transportation Act to include a timetable for regulations that would ensure accessible facilities within the shortest possible time.
We have a lot of these concerns. We know that there are very few sitting days left before the House of Commons breaks for recess and perhaps for a referendum followed by an election. We believe that in the 10 years since we passed our Charter of Rights and Freedoms, there was more than ample time to deal with the major legislative barriers to the disabled people of Canada from participating fully. We believe that the government could have done a much better job had it wanted to. We believe that this legislation, although we will support it in order that it pass the House very quickly, has so many shortcomings that it is not an adequate answer to the concerns of the disabled people of Canada.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, all of us in this House know that there are groups in
The federal government has been given the task of combating and defeating discrimination, intentional or not, wherever it might exist in our country. Until people are judged throughout Canada by personal characteristics that are within their control, there will be a role for this House and for the national government to seek out and destroy discriminatory behaviour.
The approximately 3.2 million fellow citizens who are disabled are without a doubt targets of intentional and unintentional discrimination. We have all seen that happen.
Over the past two or three decades Canadians have gradually become more receptive to the needs of mentally and physically disabled people. Canadians have not even begun to imagine the more subtle yet equally challenging obstacles which disabled people face in 1992.
As many as 40 per cent of the physically and mentally disabled Canadian women, according to one disability awareness group, will be sexually or physically assaulted. It is a staggering figure but when one thinks about it in more detail it is perhaps not surprising. After all, women are often seen as vulnerable members of society by those who subject them to actual abuse or threaten sexual and physical abuse.
Disabled women are even more vulnerable for obvious reasons. It is a proven fact that those people who feel it is their right to abuse women are always looking for the most vulnerable targets.
This brings me to Bill C-78, which is this government's sorry attempt to introduce omnibus legislation to deal with discrimination against disabled people. We on this side of the House will support Bill C-78 only because it is better than no legislation at all on a very important subject.
If the government really believes that it will adequately deal with the problem of discrimination against disabled Canadians, it is even more out of touch than most of us thought possible. What is worse is that the bill was introduced in this House last May, less than three

June 8, 1992
Government Orders
months after the government had axed the Court Challenges Program in its most recent budget.
If there was ever a tool for disabled people to exercise their rights under the charter-I sat on the human rights committee last year when we strongly and unanimously endorsed the Court Challenges Program and asked that it should be continued-it was that program because the courts will have to do what those opposite in this government will not do.
As we also all know, very few disabled citizens have the financial clout to sue for their right to have the charter apply to them.
A program that cost this government $2 million a year but was essential for less privileged Canadians to achieve equality in the eyes of the law has been thrown out the window. I wonder which member opposite will get up and defend that policy. It only cost $2 million, which is about the same amount of money spent yearly by the Prime Minister's Office to monitor the media.
The right hon. gentleman might think it is all right to put the livelihood of his spin doctors ahead of the principle of legal equality for all citizens of Canada, but most of us in this land do not share his priorities.
When we look specifically at the plight of disabled Canadians we see a large group of people that has been effectively disenfranchised from society's main stream for far too long.
Bill C-78 addresses a select few of the problems faced by disabled persons. I would like to focus specifically on what it does not do. Like so many other pieces of legislation introduced by this government, Bill C-78 is merely a smoke-screen, a temporary diversion from the real issues that affect disabled Canadians.
Like so many other pieces of legislation introduced by the government, Bill C-78 will likely stand out as a feel-good bill and nothing more. Those opposite may want to refer back to this bill when they visit their constituents this summer and say they know all about the obstacles faced by the disabled and are doing something about it.
The truth is that it has taken the government almost seven years to act on many recommendations forwarded by various disabled rights groups. The foot-dragging was taken to a point last year at which the Canadian Disability Rights Council was obliged to draft its own omnibus legislation. How can those on the other side of
the House take any pride in a bill when they forced a non-profit extra-parliamentary group to go out and produce the framework for this legislation in the first place?
Going back to the contents of Bill C-78, or lack thereof, I would like to point specifically to the amendments made to the Access to Information Act and the Privacy Act. These amendments state that a person who cannot see or hear will be able to request government information in an alternative format such as Braille, large print or radio cassette. It sounds good, does it not? When we look at it further we find that the head of the government agency from which the alternative format information is requested can determine whether the request is necessary and reasonable.
To further complicate things, we find that there are no timetables or deadlines for the federal government to follow relating to implementation. I have seen a good deal of legislation go through this House since 1979 and I can say with some confidence that if targets, timetables, deadlines and other coercive forces are left out of some legislation then such legislation is destined to fail.
Recent surveys conducted by the National Library of Canada and the Canadian Human Rights Commission have shown that Treasury Board, under its present management, has not gone out of its way to encourage compliance or even simple preparation for this alternative format amendment. It looks as though this promise for alternative formats is likely destined for the trash heap of platitudes this government has built up over the past eight years and if there is one thing we do not need, it is new platitudes and new cliches from those opposite.
As I mentioned earlier, disabled Canadians, especially women, are doubly vulnerable to abuse in Canada; consequently it has become important for the federal government to give such people the tools to fight back against abuse.
Bill C-78 amends the Criminal Code to give judges and justices the power to allow mentally or physically disabled complainants to testify away from the courtroom or in isolation from the accused. I salute that part of the bill.
Bill C-15 which makes revisions to the Canada Evidence Act, addresses the problem of testimony from the disabled to a certain extent as well. However, neither piece of legislation addresses the broader recommendations made by the disabled community. Neither bill
June 8, 1992

provides for alternative evidence such as voice line-ups to prosecute assault cases more effectively.
More important, certain sections of the Criminal Code which provide for punishment of those guilty of abuse who occupy positions of power and authority are not extended to those in charge of caring for disabled people.
One could go on and on and on, poking holes in this bill.
Bill C-78 also amends the National Transportation Act to include transportation accessibility for disabled persons in the preamble of the bill, but we have no timetable or deadlines by which to do this. Does the government expect our transportation industry, in serious economic problems at the moment, to simply act on this half-hearted commitment based on a one-line amendment to the transportation act?
There does not seem to be any substantive commitment to making inter-city bus transportation accessible to disabled people. The member from Oxford knows, as the chairman of the human rights committee and the committee dealing with the problems of the disabled, that has been on the top of the litany of complaints by disabled Canadians for several years now, but Bill C-78 does not even mention it.
I mentioned at the outset that the Official Opposition is willing to support this bill only because it is a little bit better than doing nothing.
I would conclude my remarks by saying that if those opposite in the government think that this is the last word on equality legislation for disabled Canadians, it is deeply mistaken. Legislation like this would be almost laughable if it were not for the fact that so many other people out there want and deserve more from this particular House of Commons and this government.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am certainly pleased to be able to participate in this debate on Bill C-78.
I would like to begin by expressing my extreme pleasure at the process we are going through here today. I think this represents parliamentary tradition at its best; namely, where the government brings in legislation and
Government Orders
the opposition parties take their time to express the shortcomings of the bill without obstructing it. I want to congratulate all of my colleagues on the opposition benches who were willing to see this bill go through the three stages later day in a fairly rapid process.
It is an indication that the needs of the disabled community in Canada are appreciated by people from all sides of the House, regardless of which party one happens to belong to. That kind of feeling is well received by the disabled community which likes to think that all of us here in the House of Commons have some concern for their needs.
Having said that, I do not want to repeat what the minister said or what my colleagues on the committee, the members for Hamilton, Edmonton Southeast and Beaches-Woodbine in Tbronto, have pointed out.
All have indicated the shortcomings in the legislation. All of us on the committee are aware of that, accept that, and indeed, the minister would be the first to indicate more has to be done. I think more will be done.
I want to speak a bit this afternoon about the history of the committee, what has been achieved in the recent past, and put the present bill into that context, indicating the course we will be moving on in further aspects of this in the years ahead.
Members will recall that in the short life of the Clark government in 1979, a decision was made to institute a special committee on disabled and handicapped persons. The decision was taken but the committee never got off the ground before the election was called.
Subsequent to the election in 1980 the then Prime Minister, Mr. Trudeau established the special committee on the disabled and handicapped which, under the very capable chairmanship of Mr. David Smith from Toronto, gave us excellent leadership in coming up the following year, in 1981, with a report called Obstacles.
That report, with 130 recommendations, set the base line and the standard for what was needed by the disabled community. The acceptance of that report by people in Canada who knew the field and by people outside of Canada was such that the report went through

June 8, 1992
Government Orders
three printings. There was a great demand for that report.
I have to add that the member for Beaches-Woodbine and myself are the two remaining members in the House who were on that special committee so we do have a special interest. I am sorry he is not with us today. He has other commitments in the riding and his presentation was ably taken care of by his colleague from Churchill.
In the same year that we reported, the UN denoted it as the International Year of Disabled Persons. In response to that, Canada established a special committee, as I have indicated, on the disabled and the handicapped which identified the key obstacles faced by people with disabilities in Canada and outlined practical actions to overcome these obstacles. These were identified in the committee's report entitled Obstacles which as I say had about 130 recommendations in it.
The year 1982 began the UN Decade of Disabled Persons which by the way we just celebrated the close of a month ago in Vancouver. At the same time the Government of Canada included persons with a physical or mental disability in the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms. That was a major step forward in the movement toward full equality for all Canadians.
Among industrialized nations, Canada alone has included in its Constitution a clause which states:
Equal protection and equal benefit of the law without
discrimination based on mental or physical disability.
As the decade moved on Canada progressed along with the thinking and the changes that took place. In 1983 we note one of the key recommendations from the Obstacles report, was that the Secretary of State be designated minister responsible for the status of disabled persons.
This was a significant shift because it moved disability from being a health issue to being one with a citizenship perspective and that was very significant for the concerns disabled persons from Canada had.
In 1984 the Canada Labour Code was amended to ensure that people with disabilities were paid no less than the minimum wage.
In 1985 there was also a movement to protect the rights of people with disabilities. The Canadian Human
Rights Act was changed to remove discrimination on the basis of disability whether mental or physical.
The Prime Minister's declaration on the Decade of Disabled Persons was also made in 1985. It was based on the work of federal and provincial representatives setting out a number of principles to guide government activities. This declaration is viewed as a bill of rights by disabled persons.
I draw special attention to principles 5 and 6 which declare: "Individuals with disabilities shall be assured access to fundamental elements of daily life that are generally available to the community" and goes on: "Persons with disabilities shall be encouraged to engage in all aspects of society and to participate in social change to fulfil themselves and to meet their obligations as citizens".
In 1986 the Employment Equity Act came into effect making the economic integration of disabled persons with disabilities a priority for Crown corporations and approximately 375 federally regulated employers. Also in 1986 the government established the Federal Contractors Program, the Transportation for Disabled Persons Program and the Residential Rehabilitation Assistance Program. Each of these programs were designed in consultation with disabled Canadians to deal with disability questions.
In 1987, following Rick Hansen's Man in Motion world tour, the government declared National Access Awareness Week an opportunity for communities to assess the level of accessibility and plan for and make changes in the five key areas of transportation, housing, recreation, education and employment.
Over 850 communities now participate in this National Access Awareness Week which, by the way, was just completed for this year at the end of this past week.
A standing committee of the House of Commons was established by all-party agreement in that same year with a unique mandate to examine and encourage greater efforts by all Canadians in advancing an agenda that addresses all aspects of disability.
I should say that the terms of reference as laid out in the House of Commons rules are very interesting because they give the mandate to the committee in four areas, namely, to propose, to promote, to evaluate and to monitor. These are four areas of work that other
June 8, 1992

standing committees do not have. It is interesting that we have this for this particular standing committee.
Now we have the Standing Committee on Human Rights and the Status of Disabled Persons as a permanent committee that consults persons with disabilities on an ongoing basis and makes recommendations to Parliament.
In 1988 the National Transportation Act was altered to give the National Transportation Agency the authority to issue regulations improving accessibility to federally regulated airlines, railways, bus systems and ferry services.
In June 1989 the standing committee released its report entitled A Consensus for Action, which called upon the government to work together with all sections of society to ensure the integration of people with disabilities.
In 1990 Environment Canada through the Canadian Parks Service began a comprehensive program to make national parks and historic sites accessible for persons with disabilities. Statistics Canada announced that it would carry out a post-sensal survey on disability in 1991 in order to establish a national database on disability related issues. Public Works Canada further announced a program to upgrade and improve accessibility to Crown owned and leased property.
In 1991, recognizing that people with disabilities have expenses related to disability, the federal government introduced new tax measures. These include modifying the disability tax credit and the medical expense credit.
Bringing us up-to-date, in the federal 1992 budget, eligible expenses were expanded once more and new deductions were added to the list of deductible expenses for disability related modifications to businesses.
Much progress has been made in removing the barriers to enable persons with disabilities to participate more fully in the community, but a great deal has been indicated here this afternoon and more remains to be accomplished. That is why in September 1991 the Prime Minister announced the launching of the National Strategy for the Integration of Disabled Persons here in Canada.
Government Orders
This five-year strategy involves financial commitment of over $158 million and addresses such issues as access to employment, training, housing, transportation, communications, public sensitivity and community integration.
This strategy is a unique partnership of federal departments and agencies working with the disabled community to achieve the goals of equal access, economic integration and effective participation. The five-year national strategy will enable Canadians with disabilities to participate more fully and more fairly in the work force in their communities and at home.
This omnibus bill, as it is called, Bill C-78, is a legislative proposal and is just one more step in our efforts to make equality a reality for Canadians with disabilities. It is part of our agenda for progress, bringing Canadians together to remove the barriers to full integration. It will create a greater awareness of disability-related matters and provide opportunities for new partnerships that will permit Canadians with disabilities to take their rightful places in the mainstream of the life of the nation.
In conclusion, as we reflect on the progress made during the United Nations Decade of Disabled Persons, we look forward to the next decade of new ideas which will make full participation in Canadian society a reality for everyone. I do want to finally say that I think members of the House are right in supporting Bill C-78. The members of the disabled community in Canada want us to support that bill but, at the same time, they want the standing committee, this House and the government to move ahead in coming years to make even more effective changes that will enable disabled people to be more fully integrated into society in Canada.

Mr. Speaker, I am happy to have the opportunity to speak on Bill C-78.1 would like to begin by speaking to the House about a personal experience that I had two weeks ago in my riding.
I was approached by one of my constituents, a Mrs. Katerina Vlahof. She was telling me about an experience her daughter had just gone through with a company in the city. Her daughter, Zoe, I should mention, had only

June 8, 1992
Government Orders
20 per cent of her vision. She was saying that Zoe was totally frustrated and crushed because she had been working for a company in Toronto for about nine or ten months and according to all of the reports that were handed into the supervisors, Zoe was doing a terrific job. One day the principal of the organization came into this particular section where Zoe was working on computers, answering phones, taking messages and distributing orders. He noticed that this young woman had her eyes right up close to the screen. He asked what was going on. The supervisor said Zoe, who does a terrific job, only has 20 per cent of her vision. The principal of the organization could not handle it. He turned to the supervisor, and I do not know exactly what was said, but it led to a situation in which Zoe lost her job.
One of the reasons why Zoe lost her job was the concern that the principal of this organization had regarding Zoe's looking right up close to the screen, would possibly cause further damage to her eyesight, and he did not want to take the responsibility of being sued or being liable, even though there were doctors' certificates on file that would certainly have exonerated the corporation from being responsible if something like that had happened.
Naturally you can imagine a mother, who is so attached to her daughter, feeling the emotional disappointment when she loses her job for a reason like that.
She asked me if I could have a chat with her to see if there was some other place where we could get Zoe working. We walked over to their apartment where I sat and had a chat with this young woman.
First, I want to say that I could see that Zoe did have difficulty, with only 20 per cent of her vision. I must say that in terms of her intellect, her communications skills and her energy and enthusiasm, there was nothing wrong with Zoe Vlahof. She related the story of her employment with this company. I could see that really what we had here was a situation in which a lack of knowledge, a lack of sensitivity and a lack of real caring by this particular organization led to an insensitive action which was so unnecessary.
When I think that there are 3.2 million disabled Canadians in this country, probably many of whom are in the same condition and the same position as Zoe Vlahof, and when I think about why this is happening, it seems to
me that one of the reasons is that it is easy to look the other way in many of the cases in which people are disabled. However, with the proper assistance, instruments and tools they can do a job every bit as well as anyone else.
I listened to the member for Oxford earlier giving his speech and he referred back to the special committee on the disabled and handicapped in 1980-81, chaired by my good friend, the Hon. David Smith. The member for Oxford sat on that committee. He is absolute right. He is actually being very humble about his assessment of this committee. This is finest piece of work that has ever been done anywhere in the world on problems, solutions, recommendations for people who are disabled. I know a better piece of work cannot be found anywhere in the world on this issue. I salute the member for Oxford because I know he was an active member on that committee.
I urge all members to get a copy of this book. There is no need to reinvent the wheel. It is all here. What is the problem? The problem is political will. This is a perfect example of where there is no political will to address this problem in a substantive way. Every now and again we tinker. I do not want to suggest to this House or to the people of Canada that nothing has happened since this report was tabled. I know there have been many recommendations, some of which have been implemented and some have been partially implemented. However, many of these recommendations have not been implemented.
What is lacking here is political will. I would suggest to all in this House, if each one of us had a son, a daughter, a nephew, or someone close to us who was disabled, we would be on this report constantly.
It is very tough competing today with an economy that is going through a lot of pain. It is very tough competing for time on the national stage with a constitutional and national unity crisis. It is very tough, but this is an issue we cannot ignore.

At preliminary meetings at the United Nation's earth summit in Rio de Janeiro, the government agreed to a target that all delegations should consist of at least 40 per cent women.

Madam Speaker, I am very surprised by the question of the leader of the New Democratic Party, trying to tie the problem of sexual abuse of children with the question of child care and day care systems.
I would even say that from the NDP it is totally irresponsible. I have to tell her something that she should know. Day care and child care are provincial matters. Normally we do not know where the NDP are at that level. What fits the federal level, it takes over and what does not fit goes to the provinces. This is a provincial matter first.
Second, the leader of the NDP should know something. The violence issue is not related to the child care problem. We face violence against children everywhere. With the unfortunate example mentioned, we see that it can happen anywhere. We will not close schools because we have problems with violence and so on.
I just want to ask the leader of the NDP to recognize that the problem of violence against children is a society problem. As said by the representative of the Liberal Party, we cannot afford what you can afford.

Madam Speaker, that is a shocking statement and an abandonment of Canadian children and Canadian families who need a child care program.
The federal government certainly does have a responsibility. It has a responsibility to bring in a national child care program with minimum standards. This government made that promise in the last election. It broke that promise.
I ask the Deputy Prime Minister again: will he and this government listen to the mayor of Martensville, Saskatchewan, and the National Action Committee on the Status of Women? Will this government listen to the Canadian Child Care Federation and the New Democratic Party, bring in a national child care program and show that all Canadians care about Canada's children?
Oral Questions
We are prepared to make an investment in the future.

speakeroldname: Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext: Madam Speaker, the NDP is in power in three provinces. Why, except in Ontario, has it not put more money into its budget for child care and day care? Why did it not do it?
Oh, oh.

speakerposition: Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext: The problem once again is that the NDP spends money it does not have. It makes promises when it is in opposition. When it is in power, it does as other governments do. It cuts the budget to face reality.

Madam Speaker, I remind the minister that it was this government that made a promise in the last election to have a national child care program. It is this government that should be implementing a child care program, stop ducking its responsibilities and offloading them as it has on everything else.

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, this government has axed the Court Challenges Program and the Race Relations Foundation.
It has cut Canada's tools of equity. When will the government address the real issues facing the cultural communities: justice, access and full participation in Canadian society?

speakeroldname: Hon. Gerry Weiner (Minister of Multiculturalism and Citizenship):
speakerposition: Minister of Multiculturalism and Citizenship
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, since 1988 we have had a program to bring forward integration and equality, and to fight racism and racial discrimination, a very high priority.
In fact, it was a first initiative by any government when we brought forward that program in 1988.1 am surprised the member is even asking such a question because it is one area where there is a genuine consensus across the country in support of the direction the government has taken in this particular program.

Madam Speaker, my question is directed to the Minister of Employment and Immigration.
Visible minorities and cultural communities are suffering greatly under the Conservative government. The unemployment rate is twice as high among young people in those groups. The government should do something about equity and social justice and not just talk about it.

speakerposition: Minister of Employment and Immigration
speechtext: Madam Speaker, the hon. member will admit that after major changes in this country's employment programs in 1986, when we set up the Canadian Jobs Strategy, we made a point of channeling all funds under this program to the groups that needed it most. speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, my question is for the Minister of National Health and Welfare.
Canadian consumers are shocked and somewhat angry to learn that in its haste to fast-track the approval of new drugs for the marketplace, health and welfare is effectively using Canadian consumers as human guinea pigs.
Experts at the minister's own department have warned that since 1987 the government has been dismantling the checks and balances that help keep unsafe prescription drugs out of the marketplace.
Why has the minister decided it is more important to keep happy the large multinational drug companies than to protect the health and welfare of Canadian consumers?

speakeroldname: Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, the Canadian drug approval process is safe and recognized around the world as one of the best.
Recently we had two comments, one from the Winnipeg Free Press which said we were not moving fast enough in the approval of drugs, and today The Gazette which said we were approving drugs too quickly.
We are trying to keep the system as safe as possible. That is why I asked Dr. Gagnon from Laval University to review the process of drug approval and to make recommendations. We will see what we can do in light of those recommendations.
June 8, 1992

Once again I want to reassure Canadians the system is one of the best in the world and we want to keep it working.

Madam Speaker, that is not terribly reassuring. It may be one of the best in the world but it is simply not good enough.
An internal memo from 21 doctors at the Human Drug Prescription Bureau warned the government that this fast-track approach, coupled with medically inexperienced managers at the department would "interfere with the health department's mandate to ensure the safety of drugs prescribed by Canadian physicians".
My supplementary question for the minister is this. How can the minister possibly stand by and do nothing when his own experts have warned that to allow this flawed system to continue one more day would put at risk the health and safety of Canadian consumers?

speakeroldname: Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I repeat what I said before. The system is working. It is a very complex operation within the department. The Health Protection Branch deals with a great many requests concerning compliance with regulations.
Now we are requested to move more quickly or less quickly. It is why I asked for an analysis from experts. They will report to me and in light of their recommendations we will attempt to do the best to maintain the system. It is normal that sometimes we face questions about the operation. As I said before we will answer the questions.
