speechtext:
Madam Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Justice.
This government talks about eliminating racism while it continues to practice systemic discrimination with its own employees. According to the Canadian Ethnocultural Council only 3.6 per cent of government employees are persons of colour compared to about 7 per cent in the general work force.
When will this government amend the Canadian Human Rights Act to give a stronger mandate to the commissioner to enforce employment equity in the Public Service as well as in the private agencies so that
Oral Questions
racial minorities and other target groups will have fair and just employment opportunities?

speakeroldname: Hon. Gilles Loiselle (President of the Treasury Board and Minister of State (Finance)):
speakerposition: President of the Treasury Board; Minister of State (Finance)
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I believe every employer can make progress. I would not disagree that the federal government can make more progress as we go along.
I would like to state that the figures that have been used by the organization she refers to are based on targets that are very mobile. We do not agree with the numbers that have been used.
I would suggest that the hon. member look very carefully at the numbers we have for each of our four designated groups to see that over the last four years, for example, we have made more progress than ever before in the history of the Public Service in Canada.

Madam Speaker, I am not interested in statistical games. The fact is there is systemic discrimination by this government against its own employees.
I want to go back to the Minister of Justice. It is her responsibility to bring in new legislation in this field. Commissioner Yalden has called for a strong mandate in this regard.
My supplementary question has to do with the review of the Canadian Human Rights Commission. Victims of racism now have to wait between two and three years to have their complaints considered and dealt with by the Canadian Human Rights Commission. Since 1987 complaints rose by 100 per cent while the resources of the commission were only increased by 25 per cent. How can they do their job?
In view of this, will the minister undertake a review of the Canadian Human Rights Commission and provide adequate resources to deal with both systemic discrimination and individual complaints of discrimination?

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, with respect to the operation of the commission, I am not aware of the kind of backlog that the member discusses but I am very interested to hear about it.
We are addressing some questions in the operation of the panels in upcoming amendments to the Canadian Human Rights Act. In fact, there is a review of the Employment Equity Act going on that will provide a

June 8, 1992
Oral Questions
better context for understanding what should be done when it is completed next fall.
I am also hoping to bring forward in the fall provisions relating to the operation of federally appointed administrative tribunals in general to try to make them work better and to clarify some of the terms of reference with respect to their appointment.
With respect to the comments that the hon. member has made, I would be very interested to hear the kinds of concerns she has about backlogs and unacceptable delays in terms of people getting their disputes resolved because of course the whole purpose of administrative tribunals is to try to speed up the resolution of these kinds of disputes.

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, my question is for the Minister for International Trade.
Canadian steelworkers in Hamilton and in Nanticoke in my riding are watching their jobs disappear day by day while this government fails to get the Americans to act responsibly. The minister will be in Washington to deliver a message, but Canadian steelworkers want less talk and more action.
What specific action will the minister institute to protect Canadian workers and their jobs the very minute the Americans institute any action against our steel exports?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Thade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, my hon. friend is well aware that the Prime Minister addressed that in the House last week. If there is an action it is likely to be initiated by the U.S. steel industry.
We have made it very clear to the U.S. administration that we think such an action would be quite unfounded because of the very integrated nature of the steel markets of the United States and Canada. We do not believe there has been dumping by our industry into the U.S. market. Indeed the share that Canada has of the U.S. market is some 3 per cent, whereas the U.S. has a 14 per cent share of the Canadian market.
Tomorrow when I meet with Mrs. Hills I will be expressing these concerns to her. I will be advising her that we will be fighting this issue with our industry as hard as we can to provide the support it needs, but we believe that this is an action which is unfounded and that our industry would be able to win.

Madam Speaker, the problem with the minister's response is that the steel workers have heard it all before and they are still losing their jobs.
The government keeps saying that it is going to get tough. The question is, when is it going to get tough? When is it going to tell the Americans that any trade action against our Canadian steel industry will lead to an immediate response by this government?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Trade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I indicated that the actions likely to be taken will be actions taken by the United States industry.
It is quite likely that our industry would respond in kind because of the figures I set out just a minute ago.
If that is the case, certainly there would be the utmost of support for the industry in fighting this battle. We think there has not been dumping and we believe that the best thing we can do as an industry is fight the action as hard as we can in consultation with the provinces and the industry involved.

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, the Minister for International Trade said last month: "A North American free trade pact could exclude sensitive Canadian industries such as textiles and agricul-
June 8, 1992

ture", predicting that a final draft agreement could be signed by the end of June.
Is Canada pursuing a bilateral agreement with Mexico in these or in any other sensitive Canadian industries? If so, when will the text and the impact studies be made available?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Thade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I do not believe I said it would exclude. I said it might be done on a different track and I did use the examples of agriculture and textiles.
As my hon. friend knows, there has been an arrangement agreed upon in principle between the Mexicans and the Americans on the question of textiles. We have some very fundamental disagreements with it and have so advised them.
It is on that basis that we are seeking some greater access to the market through a quota system, a tariff rate quota, but there have been other proposals that have been put forward by the apparel industry in particular. We are following both of these as options. At this point our options are open until we complete the consultations and also pursue the negotiations further.

Madam Speaker, with the U.S.-Canada Free Trade Agreement well into its fourth year a major gap remains. There is no definition of a subsidy.
Is this crucial element now being defined in the North American free trade negotiations or is a definition simply going to be lifted from the Uruguay round and placed in the NAFTA?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International TVade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, my hon. friend is correct when he points to the fact that there have been some very good negotiations undertaken through the Uruguay round.
The Americans and ourselves have agreed that we would get the broadest possible package of rules on subsidy and countervail and apply those to the U.S.-Canada Free Trade Agreement.
By taking the broadest possible package, as has been developed through the Uruguay round negotiations, we
Oral Questions
have seen a package that probably is broader than my hon. friend or many others, would have anticipated when the Uruguay round commenced some five or six years ago.
We are hopeful that we will see a successful Uruguay round and be able to apply those directly to the FTA.

Madam Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Finance.
Recently, the Quebec finance minister changed the flow-through shares plan in order to stimulate mineral exploration in Quebec. Last month, the unemployment rate in Abitibi-Temiscamingue was 17.6 per cent.
Will the Canadian government wait until the known reserves in Abitibi-Temiscamingue are exhausted to find new deposits that can be mined? Will the Deputy Minister and officials in the Department of Finance in Ottawa realize the gravity of the situation for the mining industry, which is going badly?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I know that the mining industry is experiencing some difficulties and the impact it is having on the region of Abitibi.
However I want to advise the hon. member that a number of initiatives were taken in the budget.
Canada does have a very favourable tax regime for the mining sector. There has been a major decline in interest rates which has a direct impact upon mining enterprises. We have the lowest interest rates now in almost 20 years. There has been some strengthening in commodity prices. The moderation in the value of the Canadian dollar has had a positive impact for the mining sector as well.
I can assure the hon. member that we will continue to explore with the provinces ways and means to improve the climate for the mining industry.

June 8, 1992

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, black women and other women of colour are among the groups that are most vulnerable to violent sexual assault. Racial minority women feel marginalized by the government's panel on violence against women.
Will the Minister responsible for the Status of Women accept three new appointments to the panel from the National Organization of Immigrant and Visible Minority Women and the Congress of Black Women to ensure that the panel is truly representative of all women, including women who are most affected by violence?

speakeroldname: Hon. Mary Collins (Associate Minister of National Defence and Minister Responsible for Status of Women):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for the Status of Women; Associate Minister of National Defence
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I know my hon. colleague is aware that the panel was established last year to give us a real sense of the nature of this issue on a national basis and to assist us in developing a national action plan. We indeed consulted with women's organizations for representatives on that panel and most of the members have come from the grassroots, including visible minorities, aboriginal women and francophone women.
In addition, the advisory committee to the panel includes an even broader representation from national women's organizations, including the Black Women's Congress, including NOIVM and including the disabled women's network.
The mechanism is there. The panel is going to be looking at how it can best utilize that mechanism and deal with any gaps in terms of its input.
If there are ways I can be helpful I have asked them to let me know and I would be very pleased to respond.

Madam Speaker, there has been a precedent set with the royal commission on reproductive technologies. When the government was not happy with the make-up of that royal commission it sent in new appointees. There is a precedent to do this.
These women have said they have been humiliated by a panel they do not feel is representative of them. Will
the minister remedy this situation by ensuring that the panel itself is representative of all women?

speakeroldname: Hon. Mary Collins (Associate Minister of National Defence and Minister Responsible for Status of Women):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for the Status of Women; Associate Minister of National Defence
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I have full confidence in the members of the panel. My hon. colleague knows many of them. They are Canadians of incredible expertise and I am sure they are going to undertake an excellent job.
The panel is going to be meeting with women's organizations to listen to those concerns. If they feel there are ways in which they need to expand the representative nature of the panel, I am sure they will let me know.
For example, the aboriginal circle which was my idea was something that we needed to focus on the needs of aboriginal women. I understand it has worked extremely well and has had a tremendous response from aboriginal communities.
I am always open and I am hoping the panel will discuss this with me very shortly.

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, my question is for the Minister of State for Small Businesses and Tourism.
From information obtained in Washington from the Securities and Exchange Commission we have learned that the federal government loan guarantee agreement for the Westray project provided what is known as a sweetheart deal for one Mr. Clifford Frame.
The agreement states very clearly that millions of dollars were transferred to C. H. Frame Consulting Services, a company owned by Mr. Frame, even before one ounce of coal was mined from the Westray coal mine.
Can the minister explain to the House the reasons why the Government of Canada would enter into such an agreement that was so beneficial to one individual?

speakeroldname: Hon. Tom Hockin (Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, we should remind
June 8, 1992

ourselves of the facts. In this particular instance, the Government of Canada extended a loan guarantee for 85 per cent of the term loan of $100 million. The federal government also participated in a buy down of interest to the limit of $3.75 million.
The Government of Canada did all this in accordance with the Atlantic Canada Enterprise Program, which required 20 per cent equity to be put in place by the participating companies.
This we did, and we did it because of a tremendous number of representations to us on behalf of Pictou county: mayors, reeves and others. In fact the member of Parliament for Cape Breton-The Sydneys under Standing Order 31 earlier brought our attention to the high level of unemployment in Cape Breton. We were concerned about the high level of unemployment in Pictou county. That is why we participated through the loan guarantee.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, the record should show that the minister did not respond specifically to the question. Either the minister was aware of the contents of that agreement or the minister was not aware, and he should come clean with the House.
The agreement entered into by the Government of Canada and the Bank of Nova Scotia and Curragh Resources honoured a commitment whereby Westray would transfer millions of dollars in management fees to C. H. Frame Consulting Services.
Will the minister inform the House of the exact amount of money that was transferred? Will the minister now table all the documents pertaining to this sweetheart deal?

speakeroldname: Hon. Tom Hockin (Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, what the hon. member is trying to do is to make sure the government somehow in every internal financial transaction within a company in which it gives a loan guarantee must in fact say yes or no to the individual financial transactions.
What happened in this case was very, very clear. There was a public offering of stock. The proceeds from that were received, and with those proceeds various debts and other things were paid off. The public offering was
Oral Questions
before the opening of the mine, yes, but that gave an injection of new equity to the company to give it a more solid balance sheet. Based upon the contract with the Nova Scotia Power Corporation that public offering was a success.

Madam Speaker, I have a question for the same minister. I must say this is an incredible performance today.
For weeks the minister has been arguing that the primary concern and responsibility of the Government of Canada is not in the area of safety-and we would contest that-but rather has been in the economic nature of this agreement and this project.
I want to ask the minister whether he would describe as normal the nature of the agreement that allowed the Westray mine to be used to create instant millionaires even before one tonne of coal was mined.
I also want to ask the minister why the Government of Canada entered into such an agreement, why the Government of Canada exposed the taxpayers for $80 million in an agreement that created a millionaire, transferred millions to one individual before even one tonne of coal was ever mined. Why that agreement?

speakeroldname: Hon. Tom Hockin (Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, let us take an example from the hon. member's own part of Canada, Hibernia.
Is he saying that if the federal government gave a loan guarantee or an interest buy down in the case of Hibernia and somebody made some money, this would be wrong?	.
In fact this company had a public offering and raised millions of dollars on the stock exchange. It improved its balance sheet. It put this new equity on its balance sheet to be a stronger entity, and with that it also paid off a number of debts. That is what happened. That had nothing to do with the federal government.

Madam Speaker, so the record is straight, this party does not envy success. It celebrates it.
What we are talking about here is a deal in which $80 million of taxpayers' money was made available by way of a loan guarantee, the result of which was a mine that made no sense economically, that was highly questionable from the safety point of view, and whose only result

June 8, 1992
Oral Questions
was to create a millionaire before a tonne of coal was ever mined.
Is the minister advertising now all across Canada that this kind of proposal is normal, that the Government of Canada is prepared to provide $80 million-in this case it will lose $80 million-of taxpayers' money in a venture that transferred millions to one individual before one tonne of coal was ever mined?
Is this normal? Is this proper? Is this the kind of-

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: I think the question has been put.

speakeroldname: Hon. Tom Hockin (Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)

Madam Speaker, I am sorry to see that the old rat pack is back. Those kinds of questions are totally uncalled for, especially by him and his colleagues from Cape Breton. The federal government, for example, has put over $1 billion over the years into Cape Breton to help Devco. Every day 40 more women are diagnosed as having breast cancer and sadly the rate is increasing. In 1991 Canada spent $750 per death from breast cancer, compared to $450,000 per death by AIDS.
Will the government consider changing its spending priorities and shifting funds from say government advertising to breast cancer research?

Madam Speaker, my question is directed to the Minister of Justice.
There has been a general resistance on the part of the judiciary, even when criminal acts or violent attacks against individuals were racially motivated, to take racism into account in sentencing.
Is the government prepared to introduce amendments to the Criminal Code that would make the implication of racism in the commission of a crime an aggravating factor in sentencing?

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, what is very important now in the criminal law is that the state of mind of the accused is in fact a very important factor, not just in terms of the conviction that may or may not be obtained but in terms of the approach that the court takes to sentencing. All of those circumstances are quite bona fide.
We are bringing forward amendments to the Criminal Code relating to sentencing. We will be for the first time putting into the Criminal Code a statement of principles of sentencing. I would invite the hon. member at the time when we table that legislation, which should be early in the fall, to address the question again.
That may in fact be the appropriate context-it will be part of the Criminal Code-to address the question of
June 8, 1992

how those factors should be considered in sentencing. What we want to clarify for the courts is the social purpose to be served in sentencing. That includes not only providing a mechanism for the convicted person to pay his or her debt to society but also to satisfy society's needs to feel that the appropriate messages are being communicated by the use of that sentencing discretion.

Madam Speaker, I hope the minister appreciates that the judiciary has the same difficulty with the concept of racism as it has had with sexism. I would hope that the government itself would take the initiative.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, before Question Period I was talking about the fact that if more of us in this House had friends or family with a disability there might be a lot more political will being exercised on this particular bill. Also before Question Period I was referring to the 1980-81 Obstacles report of the Special Committee on the Disabled and the Handicapped chaired by David Smith.
During Question Period I happened to notice in the recommendation section some remarks that were made by the minister responsible at that time for disabled persons, the hon. member for Winnipeg South Centre. When he appeared before that committee in 1981 he made the following statement:
Unless you are connected with a big line department with a lot of a clout and a lot of ability, you are limited strictly to a role of persuasion.
June 8, 1992

Referring to being responsible for disabled persons, he continued:
The portfolio should not be isolated because it would weaken the
position of the minister.
I think that is what is happening in this House. We just do not have enough political will being exercised.
The recommendations in this report were made almost 10 years ago. Earlier I referred to the member for Oxford. I recognize that some of the recommendations in the Obstacles report have been implemented. There are others in process. However it is not a front-burner issue.
We are talking about a large number, about 3.2 million disabled people, most of whom very rarely complain about their disability. My experience with disabled people is that they are sort of resigned to their disability. They are not as forceful as some of the other disadvantaged groups in our society.
As we have said in this House many times before, we are not here to speak for those who are advantaged in our society. We do not ignore anyone, but are here to speak for those who are disadvantaged. When we have a bill such as Bill C-78, an omnibus bill on persons with disabilities, it is very important to reassure disabled persons, their families and their friends that this government, this House of Commons, is committed to reviewing the Obstacles report and its recommendations.
I was moved when I met Zoe last week. As I mentioned before Question Period, there are employers out there who are almost nervous or afraid to hire disabled people. They are afraid of accidents. In the case of Zoe, when the employer saw that her eyes were so close to the computer screen he was afraid it might cause even more damage to her eyes. As a result he quietly let this young women go, a women who has so much talent and energy.
These are the kinds of things we cannot just let happen in our society and forget about. We cannot only talk about the Government of Canada addressing this issue in terms of our employment standards and practices. We have to urge the 1.7 million enterprises out there to take a chance, to get involved and get to know a bit more
Government Orders
about disabled people in our community who have ways of counterbalancing their disabilities with other skills.
I know, from a personal experience I had in the last two weeks, of a young woman who had only 20 per cent of her vision. She has intellect, passion and knowledge. Some day she wants to be a lawyer and I am absolutely confident she will be. It is important that all of us be receptive to people when they are tiying to become part of the mainstream.
I did notice in the amendments to this act that the bill establishes a complaints procedure for persons with disabilities who are dissatisfied with the handling of their requests for information. The government, after this bill has passed through the House, should somehow organize a way of communicating that fact to the families and friends of those people. If they do run into frustration with not just the government but even with the community, they should know there is a complaints procedure.
It does not say here exactly what that complaints procedure will be. Maybe through proper communication we could explain what it is going to be. Perhaps all members of Parliament should have that complaints procedure listed in our constituency offices and in our Hill offices so that when we are asked about this we have information readily available.
If not only government departments but businesses in general knew there was a system of accountability for those organizations that abused disabled people, I think they would think twice. I would not name the organization on the floor of this House which in my opinion was terribly insensitive to this young woman, but I can say that it is a corporation which has 99.9 per cent of its work with consumers. If its buying public knew that its principal had an attitude toward disabled people that was a little less than charitable, it would really surprise its market and have a profound effect on business. This amendment in the bill is a good one.
Another thing that is good about the bill is that people with sensory disabilities, that is, a sight or hearing disability, can request government information in an alternative format. The alternative format can be Braille, large print, diskettes or audio cassettes. These things are good and are heading in the right direction.

June 8, 1992
Government Orders
As the member for Oxford said earlier today, we are all working together on this issue. Naturally we would like to see much more attention, much more front-burner action on this tough issue to capture imagination with. It is important because it involves many talented people in the country. If we took this issue and made ourselves a model for the rest of the world, it would say a lot about the character of our country not only to our community but to the world community.

speakeroldname: Mr. Vincent Della Noce (Parliamentary Secretary to Secretary of State of Canada and to Minister of Multi-culturalism and Citizenship):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Multiculturalism and Citizenship; Parliamentary Secretary to the Secretary of State of Canada
subtopic: AN ACT TO AMEND CERTAIN ACTS WITH RESPECT TO PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES MEASURE TO AMEND
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is with a great deal of pleasure that I rise in the House to participate in this historic debate on Bill C-78, an act to amend certain acts with respect to persons with disabilities. It is a central element to the government's national strategy for integration of persons with disabilities.

Many efforts have been made to eliminate obstacles and to allow the disabled to participate more in the life of society, but much still remains to be done. For this reason, the Prime Minister in September 1991 officially launched the National Strategy for the Integration of Persons with Disabilities. Under this five-year $158 million strategy, we are acting on issues related to social integration, public awareness, employment, training, housing, transportation and communications.
The purpose of this quite unique partnership between federal departments and agencies and the disabled is to ensure equal access, economic integration and participation by the disabled.

The key element of the national strategy includes a comprehensive review of federal legislation. As recently stated by the Secretary of State and the minister responsible for the status of disabled persons, the barriers preventing people with disabilities from becoming full participants in society are coming down.
The tabling of Bill C-78 is a major step toward removing many of the barriers that still exist. Taken together, the proposed statutory changes in Bill C-78 will significantly improve the lives of Canadians with
disabilities and provide us with a springboard for future actions.
However, the legislation alone is not sufficient to remove the barriers. That is why the impact of Bill C-78 is being reinforced by a series of regulatory and policy actions to promote equality and full participation in the key priority areas.
Two sets of regulations under the National Transportation Act relating to the air transportation and personal training were published in the Canada Gazette earlier this spring.
These regulations require air carriers with aircraft with 30 seats or more to provide standardized services to persons with disabilities travelling in Canada.
In addition, owners and operators of terminals in federal jurisdictions will be required to provide a level of training to their employees who offer physical assistance to persons with disabilities such as guiding a person who is blind, handling a wheelchair and transferring persons from their own wheelchair to that of the carrier.
That is why the government will give careful consideration to amending a section of the Criminal Code to extend the practice of videotaping evidence given by people with disabilities in cases in which this would assist in their testimony. Moreover, the Minister of Justice is committed to review all other proposed amendments to the Criminal Code proposed by the Canadian Disability Rights Council.
This review is part of a larger parliamentary review of Bill C-15, which has already begun and is expected to report back to the House by the end of 1992.
In addition, coupled with an omnibus bill are related irregularity and policy actions on provisions of government publications in alternate formats and in the area of access to television programming. With regard to the former, adequate information is essential in order that the public may understand and respond to government policies and programs.
The Broadcasting Act gives the Canadian Radio-Television and Telecommunications Commission, the CRTC, the authority to licence all broadcasters and to make rules and regulations regarding the services they provide to these people.
June 8, 1992

As a parallel action that relates to Bill C-78, we are currently examining a way in which policy direction to the CRTC on closed captioning and employment equity can be used.

In another area related to the status of the disabled many tax measures were introduced.
In 1986 the eligibility criteria for income tax credits were expanded to include all Canadians who must overcome obstacles in their daily activities.
In 1988, the deductions were changed into income tax credits and increased. The total amount of income tax credits rose from $125 to $700 in 1991 and in 1990, about
410,000	taxpayers took advantage of these disability tax credits.
Since 1984 more than 20 items have been added to the list of tax credits allowed for medical expenses.
The Income Thx Act was amended in 1991 to allow companies to deduct expenses in the year they were incurred for certain renovations to make their premises more accessible to the disabled.
More recently, the federal budget of February 1992 proposed broadening the definition of "income" for RRSP purposes to include disability benefits from the Canada and Quebec Pension Plans.

The introduction of Bill C-78 is a result of a close and effective partnership with the disabled community. Throughout the review the Secretary of State and the other departments consulted regularly in order to identify issues of priority to disabled communities. These measures are included in the bill, combined with the related regularity and policy actions and the commitment from the Secretary of State that we will not rest on our success to date and will respond to priority issues identified by the Canadian Disability Rights Council.
To the disabled community Bill C-78 is recognized as the first federal legislative initiative that especially deals with disability issues and is seen as a sod-turning on which to build for the future.
Government Orders
The bill underscores the government's commitment to continued collaboration with the disabled community toward further legislative reform.

In concluding I would like to add that this morning, I visited an association for the mentally handicapped in my riding and I even gave them a hand. That is why I am particularly pleased today to be able to take part in the debate on this bill. It is indeed a memorable occasion.

subtopic: AN ACT TO AMEND CERTAIN ACTS WITH RESPECT TO PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES MEASURE TO AMEND
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my comment is that the government comes out with an omnibus bill to give the public the perception that it really is doing something for the disabled and the handicapped. A lot of the things that are there are already being put into practice thanks to a special task force that was struck here by the Liberal government back in 1981,1 believe it was. It was a task force of seven members of Parliament from all three parties who travelled across the country and came up with the report Obstacles. I refer the government members to that report. It was an attempt to remove the obstacles for the handicapped in every field, everywhere in this country, be it in transportation, communication and so on.
A lot of the things that are being put into this omnibus bill are already practised out there.
What I would like to ask the hon. member, since the government is so considerate in helping the handicapped, is has it put anything into this legislation or is it coming up with any legislation to address the issues of people with head injuries? I have a constituent who was in a car accident. He has a bit of brain damage but there are no physical signs that he is handicapped. I have another one who was beat up on the subway coming home late at night. Some people jumped him, beat him up on the subway and he has brain injury. Again, there are no visible marks that this person is handicapped.
No legislation that I know of, be it federal or provincial, looks after these people.
Why is it so important? Because of the invisible head injury some of these people have slurred speech, they think slower, they act slower, and sometimes they are mistaken for being drunk on the streets. The police pick them up, they get harassed and so on.

June 8, 1992
Government Orders
Surely in 1992 the government has thought of addressing the handicapped, the people with head injuries. If it has not, then the government has not done its work.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Multiculturalism and Citizenship; Parliamentary Secretary to the Secretary of State of Canada
subtopic: AN ACT TO AMEND CERTAIN ACTS WITH RESPECT TO PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES MEASURE TO AMEND
speechtext:
As I said at the end of my speech in French, and maybe my hon. friend did not get the translation immediately, I was very proud to be here to present this bill as the parliamentary secretary because this morning I was with a group that had these kinds of problems. I was very proud to be there and I know how much we should do for these people.
I must tell the hon. member that it is in the bill and we are doing many, many things in the bill and I hope we will continue to sit on this bill, as I said before. I must tell my friend that there are all kinds of victims in this world. I have preached for the last six or seven years in my area where I have five jails, in case my hon. colleagues do not know. We have a lot of protection for all these victims- handicapped or not handicapped, I call them all victims. They have nothing, they have absolutely no protection. For the handicapped, it does not matter how handicapped they are, visually or otherwise.
What the minister announced, and I was with him in Montreal, was $158 million. This is a continuation. This does not mean that this was started by the Liberal Party. We are here to continue. It is never enough, if my hon. colleague wants to know. I have some of these groups in my area. I did not believe there were so many. I had to be in the field to see that. At 10 o'clock this morning I realized how many there were. Usually the people who get involved unfortunately have a disabled person in the family. I am lucky to have two children without handicaps and I hope those who are as lucky as I am will get more involved with people who have handicapped children. This is why we are bringing forward these kinds of changes.
I think my hon. colleague will understand that we do have a lot of changes. Bill C-15 is coming back before the end of 1992 I hope. I think the handicapped are waiting in the field to have this bill passed today. They are really waiting for it. I wish I could bring that kind of gift to all the handicapped people in my area and in the rest of Canada.

subtopic: AN ACT TO AMEND CERTAIN ACTS WITH RESPECT TO PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES MEASURE TO AMEND
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, what is crucially lacking in this omnibus bill are specific
timetables for the achievement of desired goals. Without those specific timetables for the variety of aspirations that the disabled have told us about, I think this bill suffers greatly.
In fact, the term omnibus, if I recall my Latin, means the total. If the government is saying that this is the total bill for disabled Canadians, this is really a serious hypocrisy. For example, it has failed to adopt a specific timetable and enforcement mechanisms to guarantee access to Canada's transportation systems. It has failed to amend the Evidence Act. Instead, it will review it only. It has failed to amend discriminatory sections of the Immigration Act because apparently the act is now under review.
I would like to use The Toronto Star's issue of May 21, some two weeks after the bill was tabled, which stated that this bill is a joke. Would the member reply to that and admit the serious omissions in this bill and that the time has passed from fine words to really fine action, particularly in the areas I have alluded to?

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Multiculturalism and Citizenship; Parliamentary Secretary to the Secretary of State of Canada
subtopic: AN ACT TO AMEND CERTAIN ACTS WITH RESPECT TO PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES MEASURE TO AMEND
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, out of the respect I have for this House and my hon. colleague, I do not think this bill is a joke at all. It is not a joke because a lot of people are waiting for this bill. These people make up the community that really needs it, and if they like it, why not give it to them?
Of course it is not a total bill, I agree with my hon. colleague. In eight years in my area some wonderful progress has been made. Everything is accessible in my city now which was not eight years ago. I am not playing politics here. I am not trying to be partisan. My city did a lot and we have to begin somewhere. I can tell you that in 1984 you could not even have a wheelchair going down a sidewalk. Today I can guarantee to my hon. colleague that all sidewalks in the city of Laval are accessible to all disabled people.
Who started this and who did the continuation? This is not important because it is a success for the disabled. What is most important is that if it is not a total bill, let us pass this one through and bring in some recommendations. We do have some amendments that we will be proposing which are very interesting. Let these people have access to vote, to make an A if they can and how to do it. This bill will provide that to them.
June 8, 1992

My hon. friend says that this bill is a joke. I do not think it is a joke at all. It is a very serious bill for many people. They are waiting in the field and I must tell the hon. member that I try to get involved as much as I can, even if my children are not handicapped by any means. I do have a lot of respect for these people. I know they need our help and our help would be to pass this bill today.

subtopic: AN ACT TO AMEND CERTAIN ACTS WITH RESPECT TO PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES MEASURE TO AMEND
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to rise to speak on Bill C-78 today. I want to make a number of points. It would seem to me that the more important fundamental issue whenever we present legislation, particularly legislation of this type, is to attempt to improve the human condition. What is that condition today among disadvantaged and disabled people? We know that we are talking about three million to four million Canadians. The numbers are very difficult to specify with any great deal of accuracy, but it is in that ballpark. We also note that they are among the poorest of the poor.
When we look at the situation in Canada today, for example if we were to look at unemployed Canadians, we would determine rather quickly that they have a disproportionately high number, not because they are unable, very often not because of their lack of skills or educational standards, but because of the attitude that we have toward the disabled and because of the systemic barriers that are there.
If we look for example at post-secondary education, colleges and universities, we recognize there again that we have an under representation of disabled Canadians and again, it is attitudinal and it is a series of systemic barriers. If we look at elementary and secondary education throughout Canada, even though there have been great strides made with respect to the integration of handicapped Canadians, there is still a long way to go. In fact, there is much more road to cover than that which has been covered, even though we have gone a long way.
If we look at those disadvantaged Canadians or disabled Canadians to whom I have already referred, and if we look at certain segments within that population, for example women, aboriginal peoples, and visible minori-
Govemment Orders
ties, we recognize as well that the situation is even more serious than the one that I have just mentioned.
We have to remember a couple of things. First of all, progress has been made here and I applaud that. At the same time we have to look at it within the total context, the total context of what is happening in government.

If we consider the budget cuts that were made in a number of areas, it is clear that although the government gives a little here, and has taken away a little more in many areas, if we add it all up, it is a lot.
Consider transfer payments for education, for instance, which affect not just Canadians in general but also this particular group. Clearly the enormous cuts between 1986 and 1995, which will total from $9 billion to $10 billion will have a negative impact on this group, which is unfortunate.

When we look at the Court Challenges Program, my colleagues know that this was of great potential benefit to disadvantaged Canadians.

What happened? It was cut and then eliminated altogether. This is a shame, because many Canadians took advantage of this program to ensure that their rights under the charter were not mere words but rights to which they had access.

Therefore, I want to point out that the government has given a little here, but it has taken a lot in a number of other areas that I have mentioned. I make just a couple of examples, the transfer payments for education and that affects also training and retraining in a number of other areas such as of course the Court Challenges Program which I find unfortunate.
If the government had wanted to be as progressive as it has suggested it wanted to be, I would invite it to look at what is happening in the U.S. where there has been recent legislation that has covered a number of sectors of society with very specific timetables and with teeth in the legislation that will ensure that that which is in legisla-

Government Orders
tion with respect to transportation, communications, education, services of various kinds, will in fact occur.

Perhaps the approach taken by the United States-I do not often take the United States as an example-deserves to be looked into and perhaps adopted as well.

As I have indicated, there are some positive changes here. There are some problems. I think it has been acknowledged by all sides of the House. This particular community of Canadians has waited for a long time for something to happen and there has been a great deal of impatience. They would also say I believe that there is some progress but not nearly enough in terms of their needs, not nearly enough either in terms of what not only that which they need, but not nearly enough in terms of the times for which they have had to wait for what is happening. We recognize there have been no changes in housing. In fact that is another area that has been cut by government and goes back to the point that I made before. You make progress on one front but if you remove it from several other fronts, what is the total? The total is not great if you look at it in an integrated, comprehensive kind of way.
I am disappointed that with respect to immigration there have been no changes. I recognize that it is not always easy to look as openly as one might at immigrants who might have certain handicaps and bring them into Canada.
We have to recognize that not all people with handicaps are a burden to the state. Quite to the contrary, they can and often do make major contributions.
I have a friend who has been admitted to Canada, at least temporarily and I hope it is permanently, who is an artist of some note and of great talent. He has a full-time job in a hospital and is in fact doing some meaningful work for himself, for his family, and for Canada. That is but one example out of a number of examples. If you were to meet my deaf mute friend, at first glance you might wonder whether or not he would become a burden to Canadian society. I have no doubt that he will not become a burden to Canadian society, that he will be a major contributor to Canadian society, not only because of his artistic talents but because of his
commitment to hard work, his desire to earn his own way, and his eagerness to excel at whatever he undertakes.
I do want to share with my colleagues as well a fear and it is always a concern that when one is critical one does it for partisan reasons. I do not. I want to stress that. I want to try to be constructive. I want to be sensitive to what the government has done. I have acknowledged some of the progress, but I have also pointed out that in this bill there has been just a little progress. When you take a look at everything the government has done, I am not sure there has been any progress.
I want to refer to my colleague from Hamilton Mountain who indicated that it was a timid and toothless piece of legislation that has taken seven years to prepare. Some people might say that is a partisan comment. I am not sure that it is because if you look at The Toronto Star, the edition of May 21, 1992, you note a headline that says: "Government turns its back on the disabled". I do not think that it would be accused of being partisan.
If you look for example at The Ottawa Citizen of May 23: "Disabled, Rights but no Laws". I think it is often forgotten-

-that people with certain disabilities still have the same rights under the charter. Those rights are there, not just for us but for them as well. They have rights, and those rights are guaranteed.
The purpose of this bill and I hope that will be the case in other sectors as well, is to ensure that all rights under the charter are respected, and not only respected but implemented, so that people can enjoy the benefits of rights which are theirs.

I want to point out as well that when you wait for so long for so little that there is a frustration that is built up and that is a malaise that has crept up in government. We often do not react until we have to and then we do so in order to try to counteract that which is happening.
I would like to caution us all to try to act before it is necessary to do so because it is only when we do that, it is only that we are indeed proactive, that we can in fact defuse the kinds of problems that we could create otherwise.
June 8, 1992



As I said earlier, I welcome the progress that has been made, but I do not want people to think this is enough. In fact, we have a long way to go. We have made some progress, but we have a long road ahead of us.
I think it should be said that, although we have made some progress at this point, the fact that a number of programs have been cut, as I mentioned earlier, means that there have been some setbacks for the disabled, in spite of the progress that has been made.

I would like to terminate my remarks by simply saying that while it is welcome, it is long overdue. Unfortunately, there ought to be more meat to this bill, more precision in terms of time lines, and more teeth to the legislation.
You are not without knowing as I do that the progress has been extremely slow, and that builds up frustration. People feel powerless, they get angry. They feel as if they are not being accepted fully as they should be. That is really unfortunate because our country cannot afford to have any Canadian, man or woman, whether he or she has a handicap or not, whether it is a visible handicap because most Canadians do have handicaps, not be a full contributing member of Canadian society.
I would hope in the very near future the government would move forward in ensuring other pieces of legislation that need to be changed in order to meet the needs of our handicapped Canadians, those who are among the poorest of the poor, those who talk and complain very very little about their plight, can in fact be met.
I would applaud such a bill and I would support it wholeheartedly.

Unfortunately what happens is there is a mental set where very often parliamentarians sit back and wait until there is nothing else to do but react. In the meantime they have created a very mauvaise ambiance, people are angry, and dialogue is not easy and neither is compromise.
What happens is just before elections, and I suspect we are going to be seeing a series of these, and it is not just this government, it is a pattern that happens in many many governments, they become extremely generous. If I as a Canadian have a need today, surely that need must be addressed as quickly as possible. We must not wait and we must not just do it when it is most profitable politically.
I recognize this is politics but I also recognize that good politics is when you have the power to do something, and it is right to do that, then you do it. You do not wait until you are pushed over the edge.

subtopic: AN ACT TO AMEND CERTAIN ACTS WITH RESPECT TO PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES MEASURE TO AMEND
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am very pleased to speak in the House today on second reading of Bill C-78, an act to amend certain acts with respect to persons with disabilities.
This bill was introduced on May 5,1992 and it proposes to amend six laws at one time in an effort to improve the lives of persons with disabilities in a number of priority areas by attempting to give them better access to Canada's national transportation system, acquiring citizenship, testifying in criminal courts and access in alternate formats to records and personal information under the control of government.
This attempt at bringing about meaningful change for persons with disabilities is a noble gesture, but this particular legislation falls a little bit short both in expectation and in meeting the very real needs of disabled people in Canada.
I want to make it quite clear that the amendments are welcome. It is about time. However, the people affected by this legislation, our disabled Canadians, are very disappointed that many important changes required to overcome discrimination have not been included in this bill.
The government consulted with the Canadian Disability Rights Council, CDRC, which is a national advocacy organization working in the area of disability rights and the law. In 1991 this organization put forward a document entitled Legislative Reform for People with Disabilities: Proposals for Change.
This report contains specific proposals for an omnibus bill. The government is trying to hide behind its own rhetoric when it claims that it consulted widely with disability groups. Yet its long awaited bill, Bill C-78, does not contain many of the recommendations made by the CDRC and other disability groups.
I would like to point out some of this bill's more serious deficiencies. Bill C-78 amends the Access to Information Act and the Privacy Act so that a person with sensory disability, that is a sight or hearing disability, can request government information in an alternative format which would mean Braille, large print, diskettes or audio cassettes.
The bill also allows the head of the government institution from which the information is being requested to determine whether the request is necessary and reasonable. As well, the bill establishes a complaints procedure for persons with disabilities who are unsatisfied with the handling of their requests for information.
There is a danger in leaving open the possibility for abuse by both government and persons with disabilities. There can be requests for excessive amounts of material by persons with disabilities. As well, heads of government and institutions can unreasonably deny access to information.
In a related announcement, the government stated that Treasury Board will strengthen and promote its policy on the availability of alternate formats of government information already available to the public. No timetables were announced.
Treasury Board has previously directed all departments to set aside a fixed percentage of their publicity and information budgets for producing materials in alternate formats. Yet according to the CDRC the reality is that few government departments adhere to this guideline.
Recent surveys conducted by the National Library of Canada and the Canadian Human Rights Commission show little action to encourage or require compliance had been taken by Treasury Board and that very few departments produce or are about to produce documents in alternate format.
The amendment to the Citizenship Act that the requirement to take an oath in order to obtain Canadian citizenship may be waived for "any person who is prevented from understanding the significance of taking the oath of citizenship by reason of a mental disability" is no doubt welcome. However, it was certainly not considered a priority by disability groups.
June 8, 1992

Higher on the list of disabled groups would have been movement on the need for amendments to the Immigration Act which discriminates against disabled persons seeking to immigrate to Canada.
Bill C-78 amends the Criminal Code to allow a person with a mental or physical disability to "testify outside the courtroom or behind a screen or other device that would allow the complainant not to see the accused, if the judge or justice is of the view that the exclusion is necessary to obtain a full and candid account of the acts complained of from the complainant".
Bravo, that is a very important amendment but it is but one of many amendments to the Criminal Code and the Canada Evidence Act which have been recommended by disability groups.
The government has indicated that the Minister of Justice will review other sections of the Criminal Code and the Canada Evidence Act which have been identified by the disability community as requiring attention. This has begun as part of the parliamentary review of Bill C-15.
According to the Canadian Disability Rights Council, people with disabilities are up to 10 times more likely to be physically or sexually assaulted than people without disabilities. Often the abuser is never charged because of the difficulties associated with a disabled person testifying in court.
Bill C-15 made significant changes to the Criminal Code and the Canada Evidence Act to facilitate the testimony of child witnesses and people with mental disabilities. However, disability groups believe that these changes did not go far enough in protecting the rights of people with disabilities in court.
The Canadian Disability Rights Council made a number of recommendations in this area which Bill C-78 omits. I quote:
An exception to the hearsay rule that would allow a third party, such as an attendant, to give evidence instead of the victim should be provided where no other way exists to get the evidence in court. New ways of identifying the accused through the use of voice line-ups for people who are blind must be allowed. Finally, the current provisions that deal with abuse by those in positions of trust and authority must be extended to include protection for people with disabilities.
Bill C-78 contains a number of amendments to ensure that many persons with disabilities will be able to exercise their right to participate in elections by ensuring
Government Orders
that polling stations have level access; providing mobile polling stations for persons residing in institutions; implementing public education programs to make the electoral process better known to persons with disabilities. They would allow election officials, friends or relatives of disabled persons to accompany them into the voting compartment to assist them in marking the ballot; providing blind or visually impaired voters with a special template to assist them in marking the ballot and amending the definition of personal expense for candidates with disabilities so that expenses related to the candidates' disabilities are not required to be included as election expenses.
A number of issues have not been addressed in these amendments. For example, the residence requirement in the bill discriminates against homeless people, many of whom are people with mental disabilities who have been deinstitutionalized.
The government has indicated that some of these outstanding issues may be addressed by the parliamentary committee examining the recommendations of the Royal Commission on Electoral Reform and Party Financing.
In its amendments to the National Transportation Act which will add the words "accessible to persons with disabilities" to the act's preamble as part of the over-all description of Canada's transportation system, the government is not truly dealing with the problem. For example, there is no mention of a timetable for making transportation systems to provide more accessible services within a reasonable period of time.
This is a major shortcoming of this bill. Many types of transportation are still not accessible to people with disabilities. We are far behind many other countries. For example, in the U.S. there is now a specific and ambitious plan to provide accessible bus service for persons in wheelchairs. The government has again deferred any real action by saying that specific CDRC proposals for improving transportation accessibility will be considered as part of a review of the National Transportation Act which will be completed next year.
It has deferred also amendments to the Immigration Act. At some unspecified future date, says the government, the Minister of Employment and Immigration will be introducing amendments to the act related to the

June 8, 1992
Government Orders
medical criteria used to screen persons seeking admission to Canada.
Section 19(l)(a) of the Immigration Act excludes most persons with disabilities from being granted landed immigrant status or Canadian citizenship because they put excessive demands on Canada's health and social service systems.
This applies to potential immigrants applying from other countries as well as persons applying within Canada for refugee status. The act presently fails to recognize that many persons with disabilities are able to be productive members of society and that they are eager to make a meaningful contribution to the Canadian economy.
The disability community has indicated that it considers amendment of this act to be a high priority. The government has indicated for seven years that it would introduce a definition of medical criteria for immigrants.
There are many other federal acts which require amendments to ensure equality for persons with disabilities which are not addressed in Bill C-78.
For example, there is the National Housing Act. The CDRC points out there are too few accessible rental units for disabled persons in Canada. Waiting lists in some cities are extremely long, in some cases three years or more.
The National Housing Act must be amended so that a greater percentage of all rental units built with funds from CMHC are accessible to disabled persons.
The Canadian Human Rights Act must be amended to enable, among other things, the Canadian Human Rights Commission to deal with complaints alleging discrimination in the provision of goods, services, facilities or accommodation in the absence of an identified victim.
The Income Thx Act must be amended to ensure the fair treatment of persons with disabilities by taking into account their medical expenses and disability related expenses.
The National Training Act must be amended to ensure that persons with disabilities are adequately represented in federal training programs.
Why are these issues so important? It is because there are 3.3 million Canadians with disabilities. That is 13 per cent of Canadians. All face obstacles in their daily lives in areas that most Canadians take for granted such as employment, training, transportation, communications and housing. All want to contribute in a meaningful way to Canadian society. All we need do is remove the barriers. This legislation clearly does not go far enough.
In closing I would like to urge the government to review this legislation to ensure that priority needs are met and to place timetables on further initiatives. Otherwise this is "feel good" legislation which actually does very little to help those who need help the most.

Mr. Chairman, I just want to express some reservations about this.
There is a special committee of this House appointed to deal with electoral reform and the report of the Royal Commission on Electoral Reform and Party Financing. That commission made numerous recommendations with respect to persons with disabilities as part of its report and appropriate changes to the Canada Elections Act.
The Special Committee on Electoral Reform is charged with this responsibility and was mindful of the fact that this bill had been introduced in the House. I may say that 10 pages out of 15 in this bill deal with changes to the Canada Elections Act.
Some of the changes that are in this bill, it is expected, might be superseded by amendments that are made by this House after the committees had an opportunity to go through the report of the royal commission. We have been actively working on that report for some time and I was very surprised to learn today that an arrangement had been worked out to adopt this bill in all stages today.
I have been through the bill with some care and I do not object to any of the changes that are proposed in the bill-far be it from me to do so. I do indicate to the Committee of the Whole that I think this is an inappropriate procedure for such an important piece of legislation. I think it would have been better to refer the bill to a legislative committee so that the Special Committee on Electoral Reform might have had an opportunity to review these amendments with some care and make suggestions as to possible improvements in what is proposed in this bill.
Some of the improvements would have made some changes in the electoral law to make it easier for persons to vote than is contemplated in this bill. We are studying those and we will continue to study them. It may be that additional amendments are brought forward in due course.
June 8, 1992

I have no objection to any of the amendments that are proposed to the Canada Elections Act. I understand that the government is going to correct the language in several of those amendments. I have reviewed the proposed changes as well and, as I say, I have no objection to them.
I want to express my unhappiness at the fact this procedure has been adopted on this bill, to rush it through without appropriate study in a legislative committee, particularly when it is on a subject that is so important.
While there may be some urgency, as there always is, in passing any bill in this House, the provisions respecting the Canada Elections Act are no more urgent than many of the other changes we are studying, many of which are encompassed in this bill, and it would have been better to do them as part of an over-all change to the act, which I am optimistic will be forthcoming, in a timely way before the next election campaign whenever that may be.
I want to say that these changes are all worth while. I reiterate that and I thank the committee for the opportunity to make these brief comments with respect to those portions of the bill.

In other words, it says that any person who is unable to read who suffers from a disability is not to be helped in voting by the Deputy Returning Officer unless that is the problem.
I can understand why the minister has decided to take out the words "blindness and visual impairment" because there is an effort to try to treat this as a bill that deals only with disabilities and those are considered disabilities. There is no definition of disability in the elections act to my knowledge.

June 8, 1992
Government Orders
As I say I agree with this amendment. I am not disagreeing with it, but one of the principal proposals put forward by the Royal Commission on Electoral Reform and Party Financing was to make the elections act more intelligible to people who had to read it. It was a people's act. It is one that thousands of Canadians have to work with in the course of an election campaign and they do not want to have to hire a lawyer every time they read a section.
I suspect the parliamentary secretary could give us his rationale, but the problem with taking them out is that the word disability will have to include this problem of visual impairment, which is fine, but it would be better frankly if there was some definition of it or if there was some explanation of what was intended. The past history of this act is that persons who suffer from visual impairment or blindness have received special arrangements at the voting booths. These arrangements will now have to be covered by the words persons who are disabled. That is fine but there will be a lot of Deputy Returning Officers who do not understand that and that is my fear. We are fiddling with the words of this act in a way that may lead to confusion and trouble at polling stations across Canada and there are thousands of them in every election as you know.
I just want the minister to make sure that this is clear and in taking these words out he notes there is no definition of disability in the Canada Elections Act. There could be some confusion on election day which I think would be unfortunate.

Mr. Speaker, I will only take a few minutes to congratulate the parliamentary secretary and all members who were on the committee putting this bill through.

June 8, 1992
Government Orders
I would just like to leave a little suggestion with all members and a reminder for myself. If we are serious about helping the disabled in this country we have to set an example. One way is to begin with our communications. Most of us send four parliamentary reports or householders, as we call them, to our constituents every year. How do we send them out? Are they in French or English? Some go out in Italian or Portuguese. This is great, but how many of our reports go to blind people? Not many. I would not expect anyone to print or duplicate in another format 40,000 copies of a householder.
On some of my householders-I toss this out as a suggestion-I included a little phrase to the constituents indicating that if they knew of a friend, relative or a neighbour who could not read the report because of a visual disability to send in his or her name and address and we would send a cassette.
You may get one request and you may get no requests, but at least we are making our parliamentary reports accessible and available to all our constituents, including the people who for some reason or another cannot see.
Another suggestion is that we are lucky in Ottawa to have our business cards printed in Braille. How many members sitting right here have their cards printed in Braille? There are quite a few. I am impressed, but that is another way that we can set an example.
As members of the federal government, we should be setting an example and maybe with the beginning of Bill C-78 we can start doing this.
