He said: Mr. Speaker, I have moved that the first 27 clauses of Bill C-22 be deleted. Briefly, hon. members are aware that these are the clauses that pertain to provisions for the Wage Claim Payment Act.
No one disputes the importance of the principle of wage earner protection. We all agree on the need to enable employees to obtain wages and expenses after a company has gone bankrupt. There has been considerable debate, as my hon. friend from Nickel Belt knows,
about what would be the best method of funding such wage claim payments.

I am not giving up and do not intend to give up the objective of protecting wage earners. This is a priority of mine as Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs, but this bill cannot be held up indefinitely while we look for ways to finance the program to protect workers, not when one Canadian in ten is looking for work. We must therefore act immediately to pass Bill C-22 to encourage companies in difficulty and help them survive.

I will have more to say about how Bill C-22 will help save companies and preserve jobs when it comes up for third reading.
The provisions for commercial reorganization, consumer proposals, consumer bankruptcies, secured creditors and receivers, Crown claims and priorities and the protection of unpaid suppliers will all help. These provisions are not affected by the deletions I have proposed.
The only clauses to be removed are those relating to wage claim payments. I would like to reiterate what I told the House of Commons Standing Committee on Consumer and Corporate Affairs and Government Operations last month when I notified it of the government's intention to split Bill C-22.

The protection of wage earners will be a priority for discussion when the Bankruptcy Act is reviewed in three years.
I hope that consensus will be reached during that review and that we can start working on it immediately, since unfortunately we do not have consensus now. I therefore encourage all members of this House to continue their efforts so that we on both sides of the Chamber can find a way to improve worker protection in future amendments to the Bankruptcy Act.

Mr. Speaker, amendments 1 to 27 in particular on this bill are indeed unfortunate amendments for the Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs to have moved.
June 8, 1992

We all know in this House the Bankruptcy Act is an outdated piece of legislation going back to 1949. There have been many attempts previously to try to amend this particular act so that it offered a better balance between the various interests in a bankruptcy situation.
Each attempt in the past has failed and it has failed for a whole number of reasons but particularly because there are so many different interests involved it seemed that any change, no matter how positive, would always affect somebody in a negative way. As a result, each attempt at bankruptcy reform has failed.
This minister in particular has come forward and he had a novel approach to the bill. He brought in a bankruptcy bill, Bill C-22, which sought not just to reform and rebalance the Bankruptcy Act, but the bill recognized there was a particular interest in the assets of a bankrupt company. There was a particular debt owing in the form of unpaid labour.
It is not just called the Bankruptcy Act, it is called the Wage Claim Payment Act. It covers two quite different things. The minister did not seek to rebalance within the Bankruptcy Act, recognizing the legitimate interest of the workers here who many times find themselves the last in the line to get paid when a company goes bankrupt, well behind the banks, the other creditors and the last in line to get paid when a company goes bankrupt and the assets are divvied up.
Instead of rebalancing the Bankruptcy Act and coming forward and saying you are right, the workers have an interest here and we are going to put the workers interests ahead of everybody else's interest here, the minister said that would be too complex, too difficult, maybe the big banks would not like it, maybe the big financial institutions would not like to have their security interests lessened in any respect.
Rather than rebalancing the bill, he had a novel approach to creating the wage claim payment fund. Out of that wage claim payment fund the minister recognized up front right in the title of the bill that the workers have an interest in the assets of the bankruptcy.
Further, he recognized that they should get paid their wages, up to $2,000 in back wages that are owed. He did it by way of a new program, not by saying we will recognize in the Bankruptcy Act, by way of something like super priority, that the workers wages must be paid. He wanted to come in with a new social program, basically. It is called the Wage Claim Payment Act.
Government Orders
We did not think on our side of the House this was the way to go about it. We figured it should have been done right in the bill. We said the minister and the government should stand up to those banks, tell those big banks they would have to lessen their interests just a little bit so the workers who might have been owed $500, $700, or $800 would get paid and get paid up front.
The minister said he was not prepared to stand up to those big financial institutions and what he was going to do was set up a separate fund. That in and of itself may not seem like a bad thing to do but then we get into how this government was going to fund it. If there is any government anywhere in the western that should be afraid of the words new tax, it should be members opposite.
They saw their popularity, which was not that great in the first place, plummet over the last few years because they taxed Canadians out. They taxed medium and small businesses to the nth degree and put many of them into bankruptcy.
The government came in with the GST, a God-awful tax that the Canadian Federation of Independent Business called a nightmare on main street. The government came in, did not learn its lesson and it would not rebalance the bill. It wanted to set up a separate fund and it was going to fund it by a new tax on every payroll in Canada.
The government said at that time do not worry about it because it is only a small tax. It is only a few cents or a few dollars here and there. It does not really make much difference.
There were fundamental flaws in the application of the tax. First of all, it was a tax that should not have been implemented at a time when we were in deep recession. Second, there was no level of confidence in the business community that this government would hold its word not to increase that tax.
The universities, the school boards, the hospital associations, every public corporation in this country which cannot go bankrupt was going to be charged a tax, a tax for a program that none of their employees would ever be able to access as long as they worked for a public corporation. The all-party committee pre-studied this bill.

Government Orders
I want to make sure that everyone knows that this was a unique effort to try to bring some harmony to this place and to try to put some respect back into the way we do our business. We had a pre-study well before second reading. The bill had not even been approved in principle. We sat down collectively and we looked at this thing. Even the Tories, even the Conservative members on the committee said: "You are right. This is the wrong way to do it. We should not have a separate fund in recognition of the legitimate interest of workers who have not been paid wages. What we should have is super priority".
My colleague from Glengarry-Prescott-Russell and I, along with some government members opposite, discussed it in a non-partisan way. We looked at it and said that makes a lot of sense. In the interest of fairness, super priority is the way to go. We reported the bill back to the government prior to second reading and said it is almost unique. We have unanimous consent of the committee to tell the government that we think super priority is the way to go because we cannot impose a new tax on those groups that I just mentioned, particularly small and medium sized businesses in Canada.
The government did not listen. It said: "No, you cannot do that. We cannot deal with the big banks. They are too powerful. They scare us too much. We are more concerned with our coffers at the Tory party headquarters than with rebalancing legitimately this bill". That is what it did. We all know that. We sat through those committee hearings.
Then the government put the muscle on its committee members who had agreed to the report and sent them scurrying like scared children because the big muscle came on at that point in time and party discipline was the way to go. Forget about this novel, noble adventure of non-partisan discussion and debate on trying to better a major piece of legislation.
The government came back in October or November and particularly the businesses, the Canadian Federation of Independent Business, and all these people said: "We know it is small tax, but we do not count. We cannot trust this government not to raise this tax unilaterally without coming back to Parliament". Each and every time, and the record shows it clearly, that somebody said that at committee, one of the minister's mandarins jumped up
in his place and said: "Look at it. Look at the way it is worded in clause 29 of the bill. We cannot unilaterally raise this tax. We have to go back to Parliament for approval".
At the eleventh hour, at the end of November, the government came in in its usually under handed, dark and devious way and proposed an amendment that was going to ostensibly have the Treasury Board, through the Consolidated Revenue Fund, fund the program. There would be no tax, it said, for the first year or two of the operations. We smelled a rat and asked a lot of questions.
My colleague from Glengarry-Prescott-Russell asked the key question: "Are you going to fund this out of general revenues or are you giving a loan?" Then all the truth came forward. We found out that all the government was doing was giving a loan. In addition to that one little clause in the amendment, it was also going to give the Governor in Council the ability, without ever coming back to Parliament, to raise the tax, to raise the premium, which was exactly what every business said. They said they cannot trust this bunch at its word and it will raise the tax.
We fought it at committee. We argued procedural points. The chair of the committee, a Tory, ruled in our favour and said that the amendments were out of order. The government was stuck. We did not sit back and say that is it, I guess the bill is going to die. We came up with other options which my colleague from Glengarry- Prescott-Russell is going to talk about. We came up with a number of options to try to get the government back on track.
We recognized that if the government did not know what to do, we in the opposition had a responsibility to try to put this bill back on track to help those individuals and companies out there that were going belly up because of this government's economic policy.
We put four proposals forward to this minister on how he could have a program that could be funded without a tax. We even talked about using the UI system. We talked about a number of different processes such as a new tax on the assets that were being disbursed in a bankruptcy to the big financial institutions because they do not pay any fee now to the superintendent of bankruptcy. This government said no.
June 8, 1992

We have a situation here in which the government has decided that its much heralded interests in the workers of Canada and its interests in bankruptcy legislation have rung hollow. It has come through with 27 amendments that show that it was not prepared to put its money where its mouth is, and this party will not vote for these amendments that effectively strip the rights of workers out of this bill.

Mr. Speaker, this is indeed a sad performance by a minister of the Crown, the Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs.
There were two major principles in any amendment to the Bankruptcy Act; on the one hand there was the principle that workers who have lost their wages because of a bankruptcy or an insolvency are entitled to be compensated for their wages. They ought to get those wages.
If the workers had been paid on the Friday and the company went bankrupt on the Monday, the major creditors do not come back and say to the company, "go and get those cheques back that you paid the workers".
There is a principle that a worker is entitled to be compensated for the effort and the commitment that he has put into the job, for his labour.
That is one principle. The other principle in the Bankruptcy Act was to allow for reorganizations which may result in saving some companies from going down the tubes because we have a financial institution in this country that acts more like a coyote when it smells blood. It moves in and takes the security.
Those are the two major principles, and we have been operating with a Bankruptcy Act which was passed in 1949. For 43 years we have made no major changes even though the whole marketplace, the society, has changed.
This government recognized those two major principles. It is bad enough that the Liberals were unable to do anything at all when they were in power. They did not have the courage to do anything. At least this gang brought in Bill C-22.
The major stakeholders-the minister keeps talking about the major stakeholders-in the bill are the creditors. The major stakeholders are the suppliers, the farmers, the fishermen. The major stakeholders in the bill are the workers.
Government Orders
In this bill I looked for the balance. Do we provide a balance for the stakeholders in the bill? The bill was balanced when it had a wage protection plan. I did not like the idea that it would put another payroll tax on the economy at this time. I did not like that.
Since this government came to power in 1984 it has taxed Canadians 34 times. Canadians, particularly workers, are well aware of the unemployment insurance premiums, which in January went to 24 per cent. They know while it starts with the price of a cup of coffee it ends up that you are buying the whole urn of coffee. In my view nobody would support the small business community and the public sector as well. School boards, hospitals, universities and municipalities will not countenance another payroll tax.
We said to the government that we recognized that we have to maintain the balance in the bill.
One of the ways to maintain the balance of the bill was to ensure that workers go to the front of the bus, the same as the banks go to the front of the bus.
What is the difference between any of the big financial institutions in this country having a secure credit on some assets of a company that has gone bankrupt and a worker who has given his time and labour? That is just as secure as a bank, any other financial institution or any other creditor.
So we wanted a super priority, so to speak, for the workers. The committee at pre-study stage agreed and recommended that to the government. The government said: "No, we cannot do that. It means we would have to be challenging the powers of the large financial institutions." It backed away from that. The minister is shaking his head. The fact of the matter is that he got eyeball to eyeball with them and he backed away.
When we got into committee study of the bill, we then proposed that we should pay it out of general revenues. We said: "Look, it is $61 million." In a total government budget, Canada's budget of $145 billion, it is $61 million. We said: "Take it out of general revenues."
The Government of Ontario responded to the same problem with having a wage protection plan that is paid out of general revenues. The government said no to that.

Government Orders
We then came back and suggested to the government that it tax the assets the creditors are realizing when they enforce their security in a bankruptcy. After all, we are going to pay all of the major banks employing 500,000 people in the country and would be putting $3 million into the government's wage protection plan. Surely if they wanted to maintain their super priority at the head of the bus, why would they deny workers $61 million? Last year, the total amount of assets in bankruptcy situations was $4.3 billion. The financial institutions got $3 billion of that. We are talking about $61 million for workers. Again the government said no.
The committee turned that proposal down, lead by the Conservative majority on the committee. Now this minister said to workers in his opening remarks: "We have no intention of abandoning workers". Well, it took us 43 years to get to this position.
I want to tell you now that you do not have the element, the other voices in this whole business of bankruptcy are arguing for changes. Workers who have lost their jobs as a result of bankruptcy and are not getting paid, can you see the impression they are going to make on this government to correct that anomaly, to correct that injustice?
In this bill, we have looked after all those other stakeholders, to use the minister's term. Look at what we are doing in the bill. We are allowing the farmers to come and get their carrots, chickens and whatever else. We are allowing the fishermen to come and get their cod, whatever other fish or turtles they have sold. If it is there, they can come and take it. It is called revindication of goods. They have a super priority.
We heard the bankers who came before the committee when it was proposed in the bill. They all said: "Well, you cannot do that. We are going to have a credit crunch." It is done in Quebec and it did not create any credit crunch.
Now suppliers can revindicate their goods. Look at who gets in the line-up and who gets their cut. First we have the secure creditors, banks and financial institutions. They get their cut. Then we have the government getting its cut. Government has to get its cut with all those UI premiums, CPP premiums and income tax owing. The lawyers get theirs. All those who are trustees get their cut off the top. They are super priorized. The
superintendent, whatever charges he has, he takes his off the top, but you cannot put the workers in.
I say to the minister, to this government and to all those who are watching that the minute the workers were separated from the rest of all those who have vested interests in this bill, the minute the workers were taken out, then there was no reason for anybody to change things to put workers back into the picture. That is it. All of the powerful stakeholders have been taken out. They are satisfied. Who is going to be the voice crying out in the wilderness to put workers back on the list?
The minister is telling the workers he will not forget them. As soon as the ink is dry on this bill they are forgotten. This minister will stand condemned by history as having turned his back on one of the major stakeholders in bankruptcy, the workers.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I wonder if there is anything symbolic that a form of closure or another was in fact invoked twice

June 8, 1992
Government Orders
within 30 seconds in the House of Commons today. I must say that the parliamentary secretary just a few moments extended the sitting of the House for this evening. That in itself is not objectionable. What is objectionable is the fact that an agreement previously arranged to have the House sit an extra hour has in fact been breached or superseded by what was moved earlier today. In any case, I hope that it is a technical breach only, that we will complete our discussions within that hour and that the whole discussion will be academic.
When this bill was debated in committee, it was initially debated or discussed in what is referred to as a pre-study. That was a brand new instrument. I do believe our Standing Committee on Consumer and Corporate Affairs and Government Operations was the first to use it to deal with Bill C-22, the Bankruptcy Act and the Wage Earner Protection Act. My colleague, the member for Dartmouth and I and other colleagues handled the bill very well.
Initially the government told us that it wanted to apply a payroll tax in order to fund the wage earner protection program. I must say that in the beginning I did not find that particularly objectionable myself, but many Canadians said: "Wait a minute, this is not right. We have already had taxes increased almost three dozen times since the Conservatives have been in power. Notwithstanding the fact that that payroll tax is going to be very small, we do not like it because we cannot trust these people". You know, Mr. Speaker, they were right. Canadians who contributed toward the process had it dead on. No sooner had we turned around than the government started to introduce amendments of its own. In those amendments one of the things that the government was trying to do was to remove the provision whereby Parliament had to decide if there was to be a change in the premiums of this wage earner protection program. In other words the government wanted to amend its own bill in order to give itself the power to increase the premium that it had just levied without asking Parliament.
Canadians who had contributed at the committee had it right. We were faced with the situation that Canadians did not want a new tax. I can appreciate that. I think they were quite right in saying that no new tax should be invoked.
That does not mean that we should not have a wage earner protection program.

My colleague from Dartmouth and I sincerely believe that there is a real need to implement a wage claim
recovery mechanism for workers who lose their jobs. [English]
In my own constituency of Glengarry-Prescott-Russell I will never forget the 1984 election campaign. I was the incumbent provincial member, the MPP for the area. In the middle of the election I got a phone call at my campaign office. This phone call was from a group of women working at an assembly plant in Hawkesbury where garments were put together. The workers were saying: "Mr. Boudria, the owner is trying to remove the sewing machines from the building. He has not paid us our holiday pay. He still owes many of us wages and he is trying to take off with the machines".
I immediately phoned the police and told them what was going on. I instructed people at my office to get in touch with someone at the legal clinic to seek to get an injunction preventing the man from doing this. I went and joined the workers personally in order to stop the people who were trying to take the machines away. That would have been the last that those people would have heard of their money. They would never have it. The guy would have just taken off with his equipment, packed up and started some place else at some point down the road. That makes the point as to why we need wage earner protection programs like this.
My colleague from Dartmouth together with myself proposed a number of alternatives to the levy the government was proposing, the payroll tax. He proposed the wage earner protection fund be funded by a levy on the dividends paid to secured creditors.
There were amendments brought by the government but the amendments were such as to exempt the bank from virtually anything in so far as levies are concerned for the services given to them.
We also proposed as an alternative to financing the wage earner protection fund, the unemployment insurance fund for a period of time. My colleague and I, when the government did not want to understand any of this said, let us make a deal, we are reasonable people in this committee. Let us have the government fund this program for 18 months out of the Consolidated Revenue Fund and after 18 months we will devise something better to fund this. This was certainly one way in which it could have been done. The government would not listen to it.
All proposals made by the Liberal opposition were defeated by the government. The government did not want to see a wage order protection fund of any kind seemingly, other than the kind the government could fund directly by one of those premiums, those same
June 8, 1992

premiums that they did not even want to consult Parliament about before establishing the rates.
That is why my colleague and I support the principle of having a wage earner protection fund. We did not support the payroll tax proposed by the government in Bill C-22. We do not support Motions Nos. 1 to 27 because they would remove everything from the bill that gave the workers their protection.
What the government should have done instead is introduce amendments. There would have been Motions Nos. 1 to 27 or something like that, but those motions would have proposed an alternative to the wage earner protection fund instead of simply deleting the clauses and saying they will be back at some point in the future in order to offer protection to workers.
We could discuss a number of other issues as they involve this wage earner protection fund but the point remains the same. The minister should address both of these issues. I do not want this bill delayed because there are many businesses that could be rehabilitated with a new bankruptcy law. In so rehabilitating those businesses, we will not have any new ones shut down or at least not as many of them. We will not have as many people losing their jobs and as many people without a wage earner protection fund. The right way of doing it is to have both a wage earner protection program and a new bankruptcy law in this country.
I am with the minister when he says we need a new law and we need it soon. That is quite true. Where he and I part company is when he removes all the clauses to the wage earner protection program and replaces them with nothing at all, only with blank spaces. Blank spaces do not provide much of a pay cheque for the people who have lost their wages.
We are not asking for charity here. Those people have earned that money, their salary, they have earned their vacation pay and they have earned their pay cheque that has not been paid to them in four or five weeks because the boss comes in and says "Gee folks, can you wait a little while for your pay cheque because we are having a rough time in this enterprise", and the workers buy it. Many times they should. When it is all over though, the money that is owed to the workers should be paid.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to say a word on these motions, but first I want to point out that once again the Bloc Quebecois was ignored and not consulted regarding the extension of
Government Orders
sitting hours. I point this out, because today I had decided to be a good girl, to co-operate and to give consent regarding Bill C-78.
So when unanimous consent was required, I gave that consent out of the goodness of my heart. Then, afterwards, the other parties are asked about extending sitting hours, but not the Bloc Quebecois. Therefore, they should not bother asking for my consent anymore, because this is it. I will not give that consent anymore. I hope that the government will not need my consent, because I have had enough for the time being.
Regarding the bill itself, I find it regrettable that the government did not have the courage of its convictions. After having promised since June 1991 that workers would have an act on wage claim recovery, this government has unfortunately decided not to go ahead with its project. Rather, it has listened to its conservative members and I mean conservative in the literal sense of the word.
The Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs says that he will keep trying to ensure wage claims protection. Again, this is only wishful thinking. This reminds me of the wishful thinking expressed last week by the member for Jonquiere regarding the Referendum Act. This seems to be essentially a similar situation, since the minister does not have the support of his party to go ahead with this wage claim act.
We know very well that the existing Bankruptcy Act goes back to 1949.1 doubt very much that this legislation will soon be reviewed.
Once again, the Conservative government backed off under pressure. I would like to talk more specifically about clauses 7, 8 and 11, which the minister wants to delete with the motions that he tabled. I will discuss those clauses from a very specific angle, and I mean the quality of the French version as well as its wording. Regarding this issue, I will refer to the report submitted in September 1991 to the Standing Committee on Consumer and Corporate Affairs and Government Operations by the committee of the Barreau du Quebec on bankruptcy, insolvency and wage claim recovery.
In its report, the Barreau tells us about all the problems in understanding the French version of the sections of that act. I will simply quote section 7 of the act at page 6 which says: "Les prestations ne peuvent etre cedees, grevees de privileges, saisies, assorties d'un exercice anticipe, ni donnees en garantie, et toute operation en ce sens est nulle."

June 8, 1992
Government Orders
I believe that the Minister for Consumer and Corporate Affairs has a degree in law and perhaps he could explain to me the meaning of "assorties d'un exercice anticipe" as the French version says. Even the Barreau du Quebec does not understand that expression. I really wonder where it comes from, unless it is a very bad translation as we suspect it is.
Section 8 is just as bad. It says:
Lorsqu'un versement est fait a un particulier au titre de la presente
section, Sa Majeste du chef du Canada est subrogee dans les droits de
ce particulier sur le failli, la personne insolvable ou tout
administrateur d'une personne morale et sur tous biens.
Of course they mean "sur les biens du failli", but you have to read the section several times, and this is true, as I said, even for people who have a law degree and who are used to reviewing bills rather frequently. I will end by reading paragraph 2 of section 11, on page 7, line 24:
La demande est a presenter, selon les modalites reglementaires-
Of course, we know that it should be "la demande est presentee".
Once again, and I have done it several times over a period of a few days, I point out that the French language is really not treated properly in this House. It is very easy to see that we only get translated documents and in fact, they are very badly translated most of the time.
I will carry on the same vein regarding the clauses left since there are now 27 fewer than originally in this famous bill. I will keep criticizing the substance as well as the quality of the French version regarding those other provisions.

Mr. Speaker, I want to put a few remarks on the record with respect to this legislation. I consider it a black eye for this institution to not have a wage earners' protection fund included in this bill.
At this time when the economy is in trouble and we have witnessed a lot of bankruptcies, a lot of closures of plants and offices of one kind or another, we should take the opportunity to support workers, to show we are really behind them and we are committed to them. Yet we see
that we have failed in that commitment, if we ever had it at all, particularly from the government's perspective.
Workers will have reason to be deeply disappointed with us not coming up with a mechanism to give them more protection.
I want to say that all workers very often, certainly in the employment context, have to offer is their labour. That is their means of livelihood. That is how they make a living. That is what they give to their employers. They give their employers their hands, their minds and in return, their employers pay them a wage, a salary.
Surely at a time of financial difficulty for firms, workers should be given top priority. For workers most often, just about always, that is the only source of income they have. That is the only financial leg on which they stand, the income from their labour. We should do everything possible to protect that, to give them the dignity to be paid their wages.
That is not the case with the banks and other lending institutions. They have many sources of income. Sure, they deserve protection as well. They cannot just lend money in a crazy fashion without any regard for security, any regard for collateral or they too will go broke.
However, if a plant closes, if a plant goes bankrupt, for the worker that is his only source of income. It is not for lending institutions. They lend to many, hundreds or thousands of borrowers. So very often when a plant closes it is not a catastrophe for the lending institution. However, if the worker does not get his wages, be it for two or three weeks or perhaps even more, that is calamitous. That can be a catastrophe.
As parliamentarians, on behalf of the broad society, we should reflect a strong commitment to workers to give them that protection.
The legislation that is being amended goes back a long time, to 1949, as I understand it, and the economy has changed tremendously in more than 40 years. Conditions for employees have changed tremendously in more than 40 years.
The time has come to show a greater priority and a greater commitment to workers so they are not left in an unprotected position and not left in a way whereby they cannot even provide for their families. Surely we have to show more dignity for them. It is lamentable, it is terrible that we do not have this wage protection fund that was proposed.
June 8, 1992

Our party made several proposals, none has been accepted. It is a black eye for this institution. We have let Canadian workers down. We are going to have to change the situation as soon as possible because we cannot leave workers in this tenuous situation. We have let them down.

Motion No. 29.
That Bill C-22 be amended in Clause 46 by striking out line 33 at
page 38 and substituting the following therefor:
"persons and, where applicable, may be accompanied by a report in respect of the insolvent person provided by a review panel appointed by the Farm Debt Review Board under the Farm Debt Review Act;".
Motion No. 30.
That Bill C-22 be amended in Clause 46 by adding immediately
after line 33 at page 41 the following:
"(12) For purposes of subsection (5), the trustee shall, where applicable, consult the Farm Debt Review Board in respect of the debtor and where, in the preceding twelve months, a report in respect of the debtor has been made by a review panel appointed by the Board under the Farm Debt Review Act, the trustee shall consider the findings of the Report and where the findings are helpful to assist the debtor in the presentation of a proposal, the trustee shall make the findings known to the creditors at the meeting of the creditors."
He said: Mr. Speaker, these two motions really come from a recommendation of the Standing Committee on Agriculture. It filed a report in July of 1988 called The $22 Billion Problem. In that report it was recommended that where the Farm Debt Review Board is unable to reach an agreement to maintain a farmer on his farm, that a report be filed for the use of the farmer.
Government Orders
This recommendation is a very good one because often where the Farm Debt Review Board, which really has very little power itself to reach an agreement because it has only consultative powers or mediation powers.
Often when a farmer is going through extreme financial distress or approaching bankruptcy, it is only one of the creditors which is holding up an agreement. Under this bankruptcy legislation, it is provided that where 66 per cent of the value in each class can reach an agreement on a proposition, then the bankruptcy commissioner can order that agreement. It is somewhat like the chapter 11 in the United States.
What my amendment really provides for is where the Farm Debt Review Board fails to reach an agreement for reducing the debts or extending the credit arrangements for a farmer. A report is made by the Farm Debt Review Board that the trustee acting on behalf of the farmer facing financial difficulty would be able to put that report, if it was favourable to the farmer, before the creditors for his benefit.
It not only strengthens the position of the farmer facing bankruptcy or using the provisions of the Bankruptcy Act, but it adds tremendous strength to the Farm Debt Review Board. Where a creditor is being unreasonable, he faces the prospect of the Farm Debt Review Board issuing a report after the negotiations which would suggest that some individual creditor in those negotiations is being totally unreasonable and so there is increased pressure there.
In 1988 the Standing Committee on Agriculture of the House of Commons did a report which suggested that there is a $22 billion problem for Canadian farmers. In fact, today the problem is not $22 billion; it is $24 billion. The agriculture committee did a further study in 1990 which said that there was something like $6 billion worth of debt which is not serviceable.
We have to take into account the extremely low prices for grain. Last year we had grain selling for $2 a bushel which cost $4 to produce. The debt problem overhangs the entire grain and oilseed industry, especially in western Canada and especially in Saskatchewan. Yet often the Farm Debt Review Board has very little power to deal with that situation. My amendment this evening would increase the negotiating position of the farm review board. In fact if a farmer is applying under this bankruptcy legislation for a reorganization then it gives him the power to do so.

Government Orders
Back in the 1930s we had two important pieces of legislation to cope with the desperate and terrible situation in the country at that time. One was the Farmers' Creditors Arrangement Act to assist farmers in reorganizing their debts. For the business community we had the Companies' Creditors Arrangement Act.
It is a sad piece of information for Canadians that we still have the Companies' Creditors Arrangement Act. In my own constituency Algoma Steel just used the Companies' Creditors Arrangement Act to write down hundreds of millions of dollars worth of debt to reorganize or restructure that whole company so that workers could keep their jobs.
However the Farmers' Creditors Arrangement Act has been discontinued and is not available. We do not have the same tools.
The United States recognizes the serious problem facing the agriculture industry back in 1986 or 1987. It brought in special legislation and reduced the debt of farmers from something like $205 billion to $140 billion. That debt is not overhanging that industry.
This legislation has not made much provision for that kind of restructuring of debt. We do know there is some $6 billion of debt out there overhanging the entire industry. It cannot be serviced with the current level of support and profitability of the agricultural industry.
My amendment does not change the over-all structure of the bankruptcy legislation before us. It makes provision for the recommendation of the Farm Debt Review Board to be taken into account where it would be beneficial by the trustee in his negotiation with the creditors.
I believe it would strengthen both this legislation and and the Farm Debt Review Board legislation. I would hope members of the House, and especially those of the government, would support the amendment before the House tonight.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to carry on in the same vein and talk about the quality of the French version of this bill.
Once again, I would like to refer to the report of the committee of the Barreau du Quebec, which was submitted to the Standing Committee in September 1991. You will notice, upon reading the bill, that the Standing Committee really did not take into account the recommendations made by the Barreau in its report.
Here, we refer to motions Nos. 29 and 30 regarding section 46, which would be added to section 50 of the present Act. Therefore, there would be a section 50.1, 50.2, et cetera. I am now at clause 50.9, on page 40 of the act, where line 50 of the English version and line 46 of the French version do not correspond. What happens is that in English they say "if satisfied" and in French "soit convaincu". We know very well that this is not the same thing in law; it is not the same terminology and it does not have the same meaning. Therefore, the Barreau made a recommendation which the Standing Committee ignored, and the result is that the same mistake is still in the bill that is before us.
Now, if you go to the following page, that is page 41, it is even worse. Indeed, part of the English text has not been translated into French. I am talking lines 15 and 16, which I will read to you in English:
"or any extension thereof granted under subsection 9". [Translation]
In paragraph 11 of the French text, there is no reference to what I just read; it is simply not translated.
Once again, the committee ignored the recommendations of the Barreau. It is as though there were no French-speaking people on this committee, or nobody that could at least read French, since the wording of the bill is still exactly the same as it was when the Barreau appeared before the committee.
I think it was important for me to emphasize this situation. In fact, I can tell you why the Barreau insists and says that in the English version of section 50.4 (9), which I just referred to, it is said that the court may grant an extension of time for filing a proposal if it is satisfied. Obviously, it is not the same thing.
June 8, 1992

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: I must remind the hon. member that we are debating Motions Nos. 29 and 30 which, I believe, are not related to the motions referred to by the hon. member.

Mr. Speaker, Motions Nos. 29 and 30 relate to clause 46 of the bill which relates to section 50 of the former act. These are additions being made. I would point out that Motion No. 29 specifically relates to section 50.4(2) while Motion No. 30 relates to section 50.4(12).

Mr. Speaker, I will be very quick. I want to say to my hon. colleague for Nickel Belt that once again, he shows good sense in putting forward these two amendments. What he said is exactly correct.
I want to underline for those watching that Bill C-22 was originally called an act to enact the Wage Claim Payment Act, to amend the Bankruptcy Act and to amend other acts in consequence thereof.

The member has also made a great deal of sense when he talks about how governments look after themselves. Governments certainly feather their own nests, both provincially and federally. With dollars owed to them they establish what is known as deemed trusts. When they establish these deemed trusts, they make sure they are the first ones to move in and take the money out when there is a bankruptcy.
These two amendments put forward by my colleague from Nickel Belt would ensure that those workers' wages not get treated any differently from how government treats money that is owed to it, but that it simply gets treated the same. The moneys owed to workers in a bankruptcy situation are deemed to be in a trust situation. They are no different from moneys owed to the Crown; no more, no less.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to rise to support the amendments introduced by my colleague, the member for Nickel Belt. The quote is: "Labour is independent of and prior to capital and, therefore, deserves much the higher consideration".
I do not think any piece of legislation cries out for the application of that principle more than does Bill C-22 now before us. Surely a principle that was so clearly stated by, perhaps, the greatest president in the history of the United States having to do with the priority of labour in relationship to capital has never been as clear as it is in the principle of the amendment my colleague from Nickel Belt has placed before the House today.
Since 1949, workers in Canada have been told to get to the back of the bus. There have been about six attempts over the last number of years to try to bring in legislation regarding bankruptcies and the priority that working people ought to have in the situation of bankruptcies into this last decade of the 20th century. How we can continue to see argued what the government appears to be arguing by its neglect of the status of employees in this day and age is beyond me.
I had thought that even Conservatives of any stripe, not to mention Conservatives who have the audacity to call themselves Progressive Conservatives cannot move beyond this stage and take us back 130 years to before Confederation in their values. It just blows by mind.
I am sure it must do much more to those thousands of workers across Canada, especially during this recession or depression, or whatever you want to call it, who have found themselves left at the back of the bus watching government collect its due and watching the financial
institutions collect their due when their employers go bankrupt.
Many of my constituents, particularly in the Selma and Wilmer areas faced exactly that situation in smaller forest products companies during the last few months. I am not choked up because of the subject matter of the bill, although that would be enough to choke anybody. I am afraid I am coming down with a bit of a cold.

The action of the government is unjust. I ask it to take a second look and give a modicum of justice to Canadian employees and their families from coast to coast across this country. It is time that there was an emancipation proclamation for the working people of Canada.

He said: Mr. Speaker, the intent of the motions we have before us grouped together is to offer a greater degree of protection to farmers and fishermen for the value of goods they have sold to a company that subsequently finds itself in a state of bankruptcy.
Under Bill C-22, as we studied it in committee, there was no provision to recognize the special circumstances that farmers and fishermen find themselves in. The bill sought to give some redress to those companies or individuals who have sold goods to a company just prior to that company declaring a bankruptcy.
What had happened over and over again, and we heard this from the Canadian Apparel Manufacturers Association and from all kinds of groups both during our pre-study and study after second reading, was that companies many times when they find they are just about to go belly up go and extend the credit they have from their suppliers. They would stock up on inventory,

June 8, 1992
Government Orders
hoping they will be able to discharge that inventory through fire sale prices or whatever they do.
They hope they will be able to liquidate, get a lot of money in and pay the bank, because it is usually the bank that is just ready to force them into bankruptcy. They can keep the bank happy and hopefully by giving it enough dollars they will be able to forestall the bankruptcy. Normally that is what happens in a lot of cases.
When individuals or companies find themselves that close to the edge sometimes they do things they would not normally do. Normally what happens here is if the company is petitioned into bankruptcy by a creditor, usually a secured creditor, again a bank or financial institution, the bank would swoop in and basically seize the assets for which it had a charge on, and there is usually a floating charge on inventory the banks have.
What the banks would do is to say you need working capital so what we will do here is give you $30,000 worth of working capital. We will take a floating charge on what we believe is the average value of your inventory during a particular period of time.
What Bill C-22 sought to do was to put some rights in there to those suppliers of goods so that they could not find themselves basically at the bottom of the line when maybe only two days before they sold maybe $50,000 or $100,000 worth of goods on tick, on credit, to a company that subsequently went bankrupt.
They could look through the window when the sheriff put the lock on the door and say they own all of those coats or they own those washers or they own those chairs in there, but they could not get those chairs back out once the proceedings on bankruptcy started.
Mostly what would happen was that when the trustee would be appointed he would go in and liquidate the assets. The bank would get the value of the goods of that company or individual. It may be even the same day. They could not get them out of there. It was inherently unfair that the banks would be allowed to do that. There was nothing that could be done.
In many cases when this would happen it would force a subsequent bankruptcy on to the company that provided the goods in the first place.
Bill C-22 came forward which said it would provide for revindication which means take-back rights. It said that if a company had sold goods to a company within the 30 days of the assignment into bankruptcy, it could go and
take the goods or a portion of those goods back if that is all that was left, provided that the goods were identifiable, that there was no value added to them and that they were not altered.
It was not a perfect amendment but it did offer some protection to those companies and individuals who provided goods and found that their interest even in the few hours later was taken over by the banks' interest. It is something that everybody on the committee supported.
There was a particular difficulty with the bill. Farmers and fishermen are in an unique situation. I was told by some of my colleagues, like my colleague from Algoma, if somebody is a beef farmer and has some cattle and sells the cattle to a slaughter house that subsequently goes bankrupt the next day, it is pretty dam hard once livestock is slaughtered to identify the cattle. It is difficult when it is still on the hoof even if it is not slaughtered. Once it is altered in any way, shape or form, it did not meet the qualifications to be revindicated or to be able to be taken back.
Again, it is the same for fishermen. In the case of fishermen, if I am down in Eastern Passage or if I am down in Ship Harbour, Spry Bay or any of those places, and I sell my catch to a fish plant, as soon as I sell it, unless you do something with it, it is going to go awful bad. There will be an awful stink around there. The first thing they do is put it on ice. If that company went bankrupt that day, even if I could identify my fish-I do not think you could because I have seen a lot of fish and it is pretty hard to distinguish one codfish from another unless you are pretty good at identifying codfish-there has been value added.
Under the proposed regulations for revindication in Bill C-22, you would not be able to go in and get your fish back at all.
I spoke to the minister about this and I said this is inherently unfair. There is a special case to be made for farmers and fishermen. Why do we not give them some type of super priority, recognizing, for instance in the case of the cattle rancher, that they may sell 50 per cent or maybe all of their year's product, all of the herd, to one slaughter house at one time? They could lose their entire inventory on the farm by one sale and never get anything back. Fishermen, who do not make a lot of money anyway, could sell some of their day's catch, their lobster, and if the company went bankrupt that they sold it to, they would never be able to get it back out.
June 8, 1992

We looked at it and I talked to the minister and talked to his officials and said: "Why do we not be innovative here? Let us see what we can do as far as super priority, at least for the value of some of the goods". When the bill came back to us we went through committee. The government had proposed an amendment that would allow for a degree of super priority for farmers and fishermen that if their goods were sold within 15 days it would allow them to have super priority on the value of any inventory that remained with the bankrupt company.
I thought that was a good move. However, I do not think that it went far enough. The intention of these amendments that we have before us is to provide a little more. The intention of the amendments before us is also to provide a first charge on accounts receivable as well. Basically it says that is fine. You have gone 50 per cent of the way, government, in providing for the first time-I am certainly not criticizing the government for this- some special protection for farmers and fishermen so that they can revindicate and so that they are not forced to the bottom of the heap when we all know that by the time they get to them there is no money left. To make this a little more palatable, I put these motions forward that basically say that they should have first charge on the value of any inventory or accounts receivable as well.
I would urge those in the House, and the minister in particular, to look at this particular amendment. We have gone about 50 per cent of the way. I think everybody on the committee is proud, including members on my side of the House and the government side of the House, that we were able to come to an accommodation for those farmers and fishermen. We recognize the special circumstances they are in. This motion just goes a little farther to ensure that they get a greater degree of protection than what is currently offered in the bill.

Mr. Speaker, just briefly I want to rise in support of the motion by my hon. colleague and friend from Dartmouth.
Not only do I support it in solidarity and in principle, but I would argue for super priority for workers' wages. We did not get it. I would support also the super priority for those fishermen and farmers as they are the least able to defend themselves when the banks sit down with

all the other creditors, with their fancy Dan, fast-talking lawyers. Lost in the shuffle are the interests of the smaller stakeholders, the smaller players.

Mr. Speaker, I want to add my words of support to the hon. member for Dartmouth and the motions which he has put forward. There has been unanimous support among the agriculture producers that the government's action, although commendable for what it has done by recognizing that there needs to be a super priority, is simply inadequate. There are many producers in this country, especially beef producers, who may perhaps have a pay day once a year. Their entire production, if it is a cow calf operation, may be sold in one operation. I do not want to see the Minister of State for Agriculture doing something to farmers again which is going to produce that kind of image, with the big banks and the big creditors getting everything, and the farmers ending up with nothing. The various farm groups, the Ontario Pork Producers, the Ontario Wheat Producers, the Federation of Agriculture, have all called for the amendment which the hon. member for Dartmouth has put forward.

The member for Dartmouth as our critic for the Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs has drafted the exact amendment which farm groups right across the country are asking for.
I would hope that the minister would have a change of heart, that he would consult with his caucus colleagues and his cabinet colleagues tomorrow before this vote comes forward. Maybe he will change his mind and think about his responsibility as the Minister of State for Agriculture, and stop pandering to the big banks, to the big interests in this country. I would hope that the minister will look at it very closely. He will be covered tonight because we have already put down a motion, but if he changes his mind overnight, I know it would be very much appreciated by the livestock producers and other farm groups who have said that the amendments which are brought forward so far are totally inadequate and that the amendments put forward by the member for Dartmouth are exactly what is needed.

If they have to wait 90 days, one of the weaknesses is the fact that they only have 30 days security on products delivered.
While I support the motion I want to point out that perhaps 30 days is not enough in a lot of cases. I would point that out to the minister. I also recognize the fact that the Ontario hog producers as well as the white bean producers and wheat producers have had first hand experience with what happens when a company goes bankrupt. As a producer, I know that as well. The inventory had been taken by the securitor, be it the bank or whoever had the loan secured, and applied it against their own debt owing. As a consequence, the farmers were left holding the bag.
I remember one case in particular where it was over several million dollars. That court case went on for a lot of years. It is with these thoughts in mind that I believe
Government Orders
the primary producer, whether he is a farmer or a fisherman, should have priority rights in cases like this. When their product is delivered to the processor or the end user, regardless of what the case maybe, they should have rights on both the inventory and the accounts receivable for their efforts on the products they produced.

speakeroldname: Mr. John R. Rodriguez (Nickel Belt) moved:
speechtext:
Motion No. 39.
That Bill C-22 be amended in Clause 66
(a)	by striking out line 32 at page 81 and substituting the following therefor:
"86. In relation to a bankruptcy or"; and
(b)	by striking out lines 36 to 42 at page 81, lines 1 to 47 at page 82, lines 1 to 45 at page 82, line 1 to 45 at page 83, lines 1 to 47 at page 84 and lines 1 to 6 at page 85 and substituting the following therefor:
"claims."
He said: Mr. Speaker, the original bill the government brought forward, Bill C-22, included two principles. One was wage protection and the other was the restructuring of businesses on the verge of bankruptcy or insolvency.
One of the things the government was prepared to give up was some of its Crown priority. It was going to drop down in terms of being a preferred creditor to an ordinary creditor. You have the Crown as a secured creditor and then you have it as preferred creditor. The government argued that being a preferred creditor often prevented the restructuring of a business to save it from bankruptcy and insolvency because the Crown had to be paid first.
All of that of course was hinged on the fact that we had a wage protection plan and this was the balance, the government was giving up its preferred creditor status. It was giving up a value of $25 million in federal taxpayers' money and $15 million in provincial government taxpayers' money. A total of $40 million was being given up.

Government Orders
The argument was that there was a quid pro quo here that on the one hand there would be this wage protection fund and that businesses would be contributing to it and the government, on the other hand, would give up this $40 million from both levels of government.
The government has abandoned the wage protection plan. The workers are no longer protected. Workers will no longer get their wages. On the other hand, the government is giving up its Crown priority as a preferred creditor status. It is giving that up, giving up $40 million, and what is it getting in return? The government is getting zippo, zilch, nada, niente, zero, nothing. It has given up $40 million just like that. Yet the workers cannot get $61 million.
Since the government has wiped out and thrown the workers out the back door, my motion seeks to put them into the back of the bus again. Then the taxpayers ought to collect their $40 million. Why should we give up the $40 million that is entitled to the Crown? What a mediaeval view of government, that the government can give up moneys owing to it. Can you imagine that, Mr. Speaker? The government is giving up $40 million, not only for themselves but for the provinces as well.
I say that the government should not give up the $40 million. This motion seeks to restore the preferred creditor status to the government so that it can collect the $40 million. Maybe that is a good place to start in the future with respect to developing a wage protection fund.
Why does the government not recognize that even at this late stage there is a chance to restore the Crown priority to a preferred creditor status? Why is it dropping down? The argument is that it facilitates the restructuring of businesses, but in fact if you have to restructure a business, the Crown has a preferred status and it has to be paid before you can restructure anything.
The government has high hopes for the restructuring of businesses in the face of potential bankruptcy or insolvency. The fact of the matter is that in the United States chapter 11 has been in effect. We know from looking at the history and the results of that chapter 11
legislation in the United States that approximately 20 per cent of all potentially bankrupt or insolvent companies ever get saved. All it does is put off the day of reckoning. The fact of the matter is that only 20 per cent that claim protection under chapter 11 in the United States get saved.
I do not want to put cold water on the government's hopes for C-22 in terms of restructuring potential bankruptcies and insolvencies, but the story is that it does not save very many.
What has the government given up? It has given up $40 million. I want the taxpayers to know that. Who are the greatest beneficiaries from having given up that $40 million? It just means that there are more assets for the secured creditors to grab. All it is going to do is make the financial institutions that may be the secured creditor even flusher. These institutions will get even more benefits from this.
We now see a flow from the taxpayers' pockets to the big deep pockets of the financial institutions.
I say to the government: repent now. It is not too late. The moment of truth has come. I say to my Tory friends: repent now. Judgment is at hand. It is not too late to do the right thing by the taxpayers of this country. Replace the Crown priority. Put the Crown back in its preferred status and let us put that $40 million toward a wage protection fund.

speakeroldname: Mr. John R. Rodriguez (Nickel Belt) moved:
speechtext:
That Bill C-22 be amended in clause 81 by striking out line 44 at
page 90 and substituting the following therefor:
"the extent of five thousand dollars in each"
June 8, 1992

He said: Mr. Speaker, this particular motion deals with the wage refund ceiling. At the present time workers, if they can get anything at all, get $500. This was the amount set in 1949.
The minister, having totally thrown workers out of any opportunities to get justice in this bill, having given up one of the major stakeholders, having abandoned one of the major principles of the bill, having destroyed the balance which should exist in a bill of this type, tries to make it up to the workers by saying: "We have to adjust the $500 of 1949. What we are going to do is change it in the bill so that it will be up to $2,000".
It only covers wages and vacation pay, nothing else. I want to suggest to the House that if members go back to 1949 and take that $500 and adjust it for inflation over these 43 years, the amount should not be $2,000, it should be $5,000.
That is what this motion is attempting to do. It is to even up the status that the workers will now hold with the minister who has totally ignored the rights of workers in this bankruptcy bill. It at least tries to put in place a fair amount of money if they are going to collect anything that they ought to collect, up to $5,000.
It is not the solution that I would want, but the government has abandoned super priority. It rejected it, even though the committee that did the pre-study on this bill recommended to the government a super priority for worker's wages. It chose to reject that suggestion, that proposal and that recommendation of the committee. Instead, it just wiped them out completely.
This motion is seeking to adjust the 1949 dollars to 1992 dollars. It should be $5,000.1 want to tell the House that I recognize it is just nothing but Canadian Tire money. Try to collect anything as I said before. Only 30 per cent of workers who did not receive their wages as a result of an insolvency or a bankruptcy have collected. I call it Canadian Tire money because their chances of getting it are practically zilcho.
Three out of 10 would be able to collect. Roughly about 29.9 per cent would be able to collect, so I would say that $5,000 at least recognizes the justice of raising the amount from $2,000 to $5,000. That is why I put this motion forward.

Mr. Speaker, I want to support Motion No. 40 by my friend and colleague from Nickel Belt.
Government Orders
This has been a gruelling process. We started off almost one year ago with the introduction of the bill. The minister had a press conference on June 11. I was not here for the press conference because my wife was delivering her third child that day.
On that day, we had a new child and the House got Bill C-22. My child and the bill will be one year old by the time the bill is passed. It has been a gruelling process. I hope it has been a productive one.
However, one of the things that we did-
They've both done a lot of changing.

One of the things we initially looked at under the original bill was whether or not the old act of 1949 clearly set out the principle that workers wages had some type of ranking in priority, in the disposition of assets from a bankruptcy. Unfortunately what it said was that they were an ordinary creditor. They are not exactly at the bottom but they are close enough to the bottom that by the time they come up and get their chance to try to get a few of the dollars they are owed, in nearly every case there is no money left because the secured creditors and the preferred creditors have gone in and have taken all of the worth out of the assets. That is pretty much what has happened.
We did an interesting thing at the time. We were still dealing at that point in time with the concept of a wage earner protection fund that would give up to $2,000 to workers to which wages had been unpaid with a valid claim.
At that point we argued that even with the wage earner protection fund, the $2,000 was not enough. What we did was a simple calculation. We called up Statistics Canada and asked them what would be the inflation factor between 1949 and 1991. They gave us a mathematical formula to figure it out. What it came out to was that $500 in 1949 would have been worth about $3,300 in 1991. Probably now it would be worth closer to $3,400 or $3,500.
We said to the government when it was still proposing a wage earner protection fund that if $500 was agreed way back in 1949 as a ceiling for wage claims, then certainly in 1991, $2,000 was not enough. Subsequent to that, we have seen and we have debated it here today, we have debated in committee and in public, that the government has reneged on his promise to protect workers wages, to give them the proper priority in the disposition of assets of a bankrupt. The government has reneged on that promise. It has walked away from it.

Government Orders
It has come forward and said that it recognizes that now that it has reneged on it, because it did not listen to the opposition in their wisdom on how this thing could be funded, it abandoned the concept of protecting workers wages in the assets of a bankrupt. It came forward and said: "What we will do with the existing act, they are still ordinary creditors, but instead of being able to access up to $500 we will allow them up to access up to $2,000". That is a bit of smoke and mirrors because if you look at the statistics, there are very few claims by workers that ever get fulfilled because there is very little money left and in most cases there is none.
In actual fact, the average wage claim is about $325 because that is all that is left after the banks pick the bankruptcy assets clean and the other preferred creditors get in there.
My hon. colleague has put a motion which I fully support. It says that if the government is not prepared to change the act, to do the right thing, to give super priority to workers for the wages they are owed, to say yes in the guts and the body of the Bankruptcy Act, that we recognize that a worker's input into the product or service is the labour that he gives to the company that employs him and therefore he should be right at the top and get paid for his labour. The government said no to that, but my hon. colleague has said that is fine. Even though they are still going to be ordinary creditors, most of them will get nothing because it will be picked clean. We should be realistic. As I said, five hundred in 1949 dollars is worth about $3,400 today and is still not enough.
My hon. colleague would say: "Let's put it at $5,000". On the outside chance that a couple of those companies will not be picked clean by the big banks and financial institutions, maybe there would be a little bit of light at the end of the tunnel for those workers who are losing the value of their labour.
The problem we have with all this really irks me. Those usually least able to afford the loss are the workers. People working at a fast food place or at a
convenience store at $4.50 an hour might be owed $400 in wages.
Some $400 less is not going to make one iota of difference to the big bank. It will not make any difference at all. The banks will still make record profits next year just like they did last year in the middle of the recession. However $400 to single parents who work in an awful job for $4.50 an hour means the difference between whether or not they can put food on the table for their children or whether or not they go to the food bank or to the church to get food to feed their children in week three of the month instead of week four of the month.
If it could not find the money, surely to goodness the government could have found some other way to address that real concern. Instead of looking after the interests of the big banks and instead of telling us all the time that they are concerned about the urban poor, the rural poor, the single parents and all such stuff, it had an opportunity to put its money where its mouth is and to look after the ones at the bottom of the scale, the ones at the bottom of the ladder, and it did not do it.
The amendment of my hon. colleague will be a little bit of light but for all too few of them, but I am very proud to stand and say that the Liberal Party supports this motion. We would have liked to have seen super priority. We would have liked to have seen those individuals looked after properly. However, in the absence of that, this is a step in the right direction.
