speakeroldname: Mr. John R. Rodriguez (Nickel Belt) moved:
speechtext:
Motion No. 42
That Bill C-22 be amended in clause 81 by adding immediately
after line 35 at page 91 the following:
"(1.1) Where, in the opinion of the trustee, payment of the whole or part of a claim under paragraph (l)(d) cannot be made within fifteen days of receipt of the claim, the trustee may borrow such sum as is necessary for payment of the claim or part of the claim provided that the proceeds to be likely realized from the property of the bankrupt will be, in the opinion of the trustee, sufficient to repay the loan with interests.
(1.2) In respect of a loan made under subsection (1.1), the lender has, for purposes of repayment of the loan with interests, all the rights and entitlement of the claimant under paragraph (l)(d)".
He said: Mr. Speaker, on this one I have to appeal to common sense on the other side. I now recognize that I have wound down my clock on trying to persuade the government that something has to be done with respect to workers in an insolvent situation or in a bankrupt situation where their wages have not been paid.
We know that under the current practice only 30 per cent of those workers ever collect anything. I want to make it crystal clear that I do not consider the workers' wages being paid either through a super priority or a
Government Orders
wage fund as some sort of social program. It is not a social program.
I remember the member for Mississauga South kept repeating in committee that somehow or other by paying workers what they had worked for, earned and were entitled to but were never paid was somehow or other a social program.
If that is a social program then I would suggest it is social welfare to pay the banks what is owed them when a company goes bankrupt.
There is no difference here.

As my colleague says, there is no difference, absolutely no difference. It is money that is owed to workers.
Having fought this battle all along in committee and having arrived at this point workers under the present regime, even the 30 per cent who are collecting, ought to be able to collect it with dispatch, with expediency.
This particular amendment would allow for that expediency so that there are no delays for the 30 per cent to go and collect from Mr. Bumble the shekels that are owed to them.
I can just see it. They would have to go to the trustee and apply and the trustee would establish whether they were entitled to get something. They are in the 30 per cent. Lo and behold after long periods of time, months, they would then get whatever they are entitled to.
This amendment proposes to allow for some flexibility in the system. It would allow the trustee to borrow the money that is owed to the workers because he may not have liquidated the assets and within 15 days to pay the workers.
That is not a difficult concept. That could very well bridge the period between when the company was closed and their eligibility for unemployment insurance.
What are workers supposed to do while they are waiting for the trustee to dispense these few shekels Mr. Bumble is offering them? They are supposed to go on welfare, I presume. I presume that the state now has to support them with welfare when they have wages they are entitled to and did not get. Unemployment insurance does not activate the claim under the present rules.

June 8, 1992
Government Orders
On this side of the House we were so forthcoming with positive proposals. It is not as if we just hung on to the super priority and that was the only solution. In fact one of the solutions we put forward to this problem of workers' wages was an amendment to the Unemployment Insurance Act that would allow workers to activate their claims.
This government wanted solutions. Our committee and individual members-I know my colleague from Dartmouth and I did so-approached the minister with solutions. It is not as if we were just opposing for opposition sake. We were positively critical. We met with the minister. On every one of the proposals we put forward it was nyet, nyet. I almost thought he was playing on a Soviet hockey team. He had learned his lessons well. Nothing, nothing, nothing was acceptable.
We had the best talents this House could assemble on the committee. We had proposed several possible solutions. Every single one was turned down. We started to ask ourselves the question: Was this minister really interested in a solution, or was he simply just marching to the drums of the people in the ivory towers on Bay Street? Was he listening to Main Street or was he listening to Bay Street?
I kind of like the minister. He is a likeable fellow. He has a lot of good qualities that need to be developed, but came to the sad conclusion-
Oh, oh.

The Ayn Rand of the Tory caucus sat in our committee when we first studied this bill. She went from one success to another. She left us to go on to the Constitution committee, now known as the Dobbie- Beaudoin committee. I heard she was equally successful on that committee as she had been in the initial stages of our committee. After she left we did it all.
Ayn Rand?

Ayn Rand of the Tory caucus. It is sad to say that I have to come to the conclusion that the minister was not really interested in a solution for workers. It is a sad commentary that in fact he has taken one aspect of his portfolio much more seriously than the other. He is known as the Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs, but I have to say that he has taken the
corporate part of his portfolio much more seriously than he has taken the consumer side of his portfolio.
There should be no joy in the minister's heart. He has totally left out one of the major stakeholders. If we do not do it now, another 43 years will go by and we will never ever correct this injustice for workers who have lost their wages as a result of a bankruptcy.

speakeroldname: Hon. Pierre Blais (Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs and Minister of State (Agriculture)):
speakerposition: Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs; Minister of State (Agriculture)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my hon. friend from Nickel Belt has said that he is sad. I am sad too, listening to what he says.
I think my hon. friend is fair. We have worked together a long time to try to bring this bill before the House. We tried to respond to and to address concerns of Canadians on this legislation.
I do not want to be too specific on this particular element. I spoke to my hon. friend privately and I will repeat it. On the 15-day proposal, we all know that trustees have the right to borrow money and they do so often. There is a technical problem, and my hon. friend understands it. It is not that easy to force trustees to do anything when they enter a bankruptcy or a business that is going bankrupt.

Mr. Speaker, to repeat what I just said, it is somewhat unrealistic to allow a period of two weeks and oblige people to stick to that timeframe. It is practically impossible to meet this kind of deadline. Let me explain.
The right to borrow money is there. It was in the act and still is, and I am sure that right will be respected. We have made a number of improvements that will speed up the process, as the hon. member is aware, and the timeframe will probably be tightened.
In most cases, bankruptcies are settled in a matter of days. Some are settled in a matter of months or years, but these are not the majority.
I expect that most cases will take less time to settle, thanks to new procedures and changes in the legislation.
I will not repeat all the amendments that were proposed, but I just want to mention that particular one, like the previous one, on which I did not comment specifically. The hon. member wants the ceiling set at $5,000, while the average claim is now around $1,000. That would be useless, considering the average is $1,000. With a ceiling of $2,000 we would be able to cover most claims.
June 8, 1992

Basically this is a very good bill. It was improved with the help of the hon. member for Dartmouth and the hon. member for Nickel Belt, who worked very hard. I realize they made some nasty remarks about me today, but that is all part of the game. I appreciated their comments throughout this process, a long and sometime arduous one, but as I have said before, I can take criticism, depending on the situation.
When we made some major changes in the bill, I said I accepted their criticism. Hon. members are aware there is a provision in this bill which stipulates that the legislation is to be reviewed within three years, a relatively short period of time for a bill. However, the government is committed, and we will review the bill, and I hope that once the bill comes into force, we will be able to work together to finally find a way to deal with the remaining issue of workers unpaid wages.
Together we will consider how this should be done, and I am sure we will succeed.

Mr. Speaker, I listened intently to the words of the minister. I thought he certainly had a much thicker skin than what he just gave us a glimpse of. He said that his colleagues are being very unkind to him.
I want to tell the hon. minister that if his colleagues on this side of the House are being unkind to him, he would have drowned in this bill a number of months ago. When his bill floundered because of some of the nonsense that was being played back in November by sneaking in amendments at the last minute and holding little press conferences, my hon. colleague from Nickel Belt and I could have left him to flounder on the rocks.
We got into a committee and when we got into that committee there was an amendment put forward and we argued, my colleague from Nickel Belt and my colleague from Glengarry-Prescott-Russell and I, that the motion was out of order and the motion was deemed out of order by the chair after he consulted with the clerk. At that point in time they were prepared to move a motion to effectively overrule the chair.
The hon. parliamentary secretary over there knows it was the opposition members who said before if you do anything on this, you had better recess the committee
Government Orders
and consult with your people because you may kill the bill. If it were not for the comments made by the members of the opposition, this bill could have come back here and been ruled out of order.
When the minister talks about whether we have been kind or unkind to him today, when he could not find any money through the Minister of Finance to fund the wage earner protection fund, which we are talking about here, so that workers' wages could be paid, it was my colleague and I who went forward and met with him on a number of occasions and tried to help him out of his bind with his colleagues. His colleagues would not listen to him when he tried to get some money.
We sat down and said: "You told us early in the bill that you wanted a wage claim payment act because you felt that the interest of workers were not being looked after in the old bill. You said that you need a mechanism so there was certainty of payment and immediacy of payment". Those were the two criteria: certainty and immediacy of payment. My colleague from Glengarry- Prescott-Russell and I went forward and gave them a number of solutions.
They did not want to listen to super priority so we were innovative. We were very kind to the minister. We did not abandon the minister. We were not partisan. We sat down and tried to get him out of the shemozzle that he got himself in.
One of the things we said was take it out of general revenues so there was certainty and immediacy of payment and a balancing of the bill vis-a-vis the workers rights. We said: "Take it out of it for 18 months, Mr. Minister. Go to your Minister of Finance and say you will pay for it out of general revenues for 18 months and during that period of time put a body or a board in place to come up with a permanent funding mechanism". Maybe at that point in time it would be a tax and maybe the Tory's economic policies would have changed, or the government would have changed I hope, and we would be back into good times. We would not be in a recession any more.
The minister said that would not do. In order to make sure there was immediacy and certainty of payment which this amendment of my colleague seeks to do right now, we said to the minister what he should do.

Government Orders
Last year, 1991, a record year for bankruptcies because of this government's policies, there was $4.3 billion worth of assets from those bankrupt companies and bankrupt individuals.
I went to the Superintendent of Bankruptcies and I asked: "Is there not a fee charged on the assets as they get paid out?" They call them dividends. As the dividends get paid out to the creditors you charge a fee on them. The Superintendent of Bankruptcies said: "Yes, we do". I asked: "How much money do you get in?" The superintendent said $6 million.
I am not very good at math but it would appear there is a problem here because there was a 1 per cent or 2 per cent floating charge depending on how much; if it was $1 million, or under, or over. It did not make any sense to me so I asked if that got charged on all assets? He said: "No, Mr. MacDonald, it does not. The assets or dividends paid to secured creditors", which means the banks, "we do not charge them a fee". The only fee that gets charged is a fee charged on dividends paid to ordinary and preferred creditors. That is the only one.
We said to the minister that in order to get certainty and immediacy of payment, we will support a tax on the dividends that are paid out to financial institutions like the big banks.
Yes.

If you would put a 1 per
cent charge on it, you would raise more money than this program would cost the government in five years. We told him that and he said: "That is innovative but I do not think we can do it". He did not have the political will to do it.
Shame.

If you want certainty and immediacy of payment for those poor workers at $4.50 an hour, as my colleague said, that are going to be forced out on welfare when they do not get their last two weeks' wages, we said go to the UI fund and all you have to do in the UI fund is look. We thought the act was broad enough that the minister could have given authority to individuals with UI. It could have back dated the claim to the last pay period they actually got paid for. It is not going to take any money.
"No," he said "we cannot do that because it is on the UI system". We both said: "Well if you want us to pass this bill you are telling us it is going to save all of these jobs of these workers and, if that is the case, the UI system has saved a lot of money".
What is so wrong with trying to get some immediacy and certainty of payment for those people, the poorest of the poor, the dispossessed, those workers on the plant floor getting $4.50 per hour who cannot even pay their rent, who live below the poverty line? The minister never listened to any of it. I do not know if he did not have the political clout or what.
I want to tell the minister we did try to help him out. We are not being unkind to him. He listened. His colleagues did not listen to him. That was the problem. I want to support Motion No. 40 and the last motion we are dealing with, Motion No. 42.
The minister could not get his colleagues to agree on all of those good proposals we put forward in the spirit of non-partisanship in private meetings over and over again to get this thing done. All this motion does is basically say for those very few cases under the existing law, those 30 per cent of cases that might get something out of the assets of a bankruptcy, do not let them wait six months. By that point in time they are going to be pretty hungry.
All he said is that the effect of this motion would be to allow the trustee in bankruptcy, when he or she believed there was sufficient assets for fuller partial payment of wages-when they get down to ordinary creditor status- where there was full or partial payment available, to borrow the money and to pay those poor workers. That is all it does. There would be promptness of payment; maybe not the certainty we sought, but promptness.
I would like to support this. The minister may think he is having a bad day. I think he is actually having quite a good day. We have been extremely helpful on this side of the House in allowing this debate to go on a little longer.
We do want to see these positive changes to the bill, but we have to in this final hour once more show the government that there were other ways to proceed with the wage earner protection fund. We hope that over the next 24 hours, it reviews the positions that we put forward.
